editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: As it hath been often playd in the blacke Fryars, by the Children of the Reuels.
Imprinted at London, and are to bee ſold by Iohn Hodgets in Paules Churchyard. 1606.

div.stage: ¶. Enter ſeuerally 3. Gentlemen, as to ſee a play.

sp.p: HOw now gallants, what iſt? what iſt?
The Ile of Gulls.
The Ile of Gulls, what ſhould that be?
A play by the name, but come ſhals quarter our ſelues?
If ſome had had the wit to doe ſo in time, they might ha ſaude the hangman a labour. But come boy, furniſh vs with ſtooles.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Pardon me ſir, my office is to ſpeake a Prologue, not to prouide you ſtooles.
And you were the Epilogue to ſir-
Fie be not inciuill: doſt heare youth, prethe whats he that diſcouerd your new found Land, the Ile of Gulls? what is hee?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: A meere ſtranger ſir.
A ſtranger? the better welcome: comes hee Eaſt-ward, Weſt-ward, or North-ward hoe?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: None of the three waies I aſſure you.
Prethe where is he?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Not on his knees in a corner, to Apollo praying that his play may hold in a good hand at Paſſadge, not on the ſtage amongſt gallants, preparing a beſpoke Plaudite; but cloſe in his ſtudie writing hard, to get him a handſome ſuite againſt Sommer.
And where ſits his friends? hath he not a prepard company of gallants, to aplaud his ieſts, and grace out his play.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: None I proteſt: Doe Poets vſe to beſpeake their Auditory.
The beſt in grace doe, and but for that, ſome that I know, had neuer had their grace in Poetry till this day.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Then muſt our Author looke for a certaine diſgrace, for he is altogether vnfurniſht of ſuch a friendly audience.
Then he muſt lay his tryall vpon God and good wits. But why doth he call his play The Ile of Gulls, it begets much expectation.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p:
Not out of any dogged diſpoſition, not that it figures a 〈…〉
certaine ſtate, or priuate gouernment: farre be that ſuppoſition 〈◊〉
the thought of any indifferent Auditor: and the argument beeing a little ſtring or Riuolet, drawne frō the full ſtreine of the right worthy Gentleman, Sir Phillip Sydneys well knowne Archadea, confirmes it: onely a Duke to make tryall of certaine experiments, retyres with his retinue into a Nameleſſe deſart. Now as well for faſhion ſake, as that all thoſe which haue to doe in that deſart, are guld in the reach of their hopes, therefore hee calls it, (and as hee preſumes, not improperlie) The Ile of Gulls.

Out a queſtion he hath promiſed thee ſome fee, thou pleadeſt ſo hard for him, but and he be a right Poet hee will neuer performe it. But what method obſerues hee in his play, iſt any thing Criticall? Are Lawyers fees, and Cittizens wiues laid open in it: I loue to heare vice anotomizd, & abuſe let blood in the maiſter vaine, is there any great mans life charactred int?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: None I proteſt ſir, only in the perſon of Dametas he expreſſes to the life the monſtrous and deformed ſhape of vice, aſwell to beget a lothing of abuſe, as that his villanie may giue the greater luſter to the vertuous diſpoſitions of true-borne gentilitie.
All thats nothing to mee, and there be not Wormewood water and Copperes int, Ile not like it, ſhould Apollo write it, and Roſius himſelfe act it.

Fie vpon thee, thou art too too Criticall: is there any good baudry int, ieſts of an ell deepe, and a fathome broad, good cuckolding, may a couple of young-ſetters vp learne to doe well int? Giue me a ſceane of venery, that will make a mens ſpirrits ſtand on theyr typtoes, and die his bloode in a deepe ſcarlet, like your Ouids Ars Amandi, there flowes the true Spring-head of Poetry, and the verie Chriſtall fount of Parnaſſus.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Chaſt eares would neuer endure it ſir.
Chaſt eares, now deafenes light vppon em, what ſhould chaſt eares doe at a play.
Tis ſtrange now, I am of neither a both your opinions, I like neither rayling nor baudry: no, giue mee a ſtately pend hiſtorie, as thus, The rugged windes, with rude and ragged ruffes. &c.
Fie vpont, meere Fuſtian; I had rather heare two good baudie ieſts, then a whole play of ſuch teare-cat thunderclaps.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p:
Alas Gentlemen, how iſt poſsible to content you? you will
〈◊〉 rayling, and inuectiues, which our Authour neither dares, nor
affects: you baudy and ſcurrill ieſts, which neither becomes his modeſtie to write, nor the eare of a generous Auditory to heare: you muſt ha ſwelling compariſons, an • bumbaſt Epithites, which are as fit for the body of a C ••• edie, as Hercules ſhooe for the foote of a Pygmey: yet all theſe we muſt haue, and all in one play; or tis alreadie condemnd to the hell of eternall diſgrace.
Looke toot, if there be not gall int, it ſhall not paſſe.
If it be not baudie, tis impoſsible to paſſe.
If it be both Criticall and baudy, if it be not high written, both your Poet and the houſe to, looſe a friend of me.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Nay I beſeech you ſir, if you be his friend, ſtand ſo to him ſtill, for he hath too many enemies already, in whoſe iudgements, he and his labours ſtand excommunicate, as though vnworthy to preſent themſelues in this aſſembly.
Enemies, nays foote then theres ſome hope in's play, for Enuie neuer workes but againſt deſert and merrit. If hee be enuied theres ſome worth in him, and Ile ſee out his play for that onely.
Faith and Ile ſee an act or two out, but I tell you afore-hand I cannot ſee it out.
Not ſee it out? your reaſon.
Fore God I lay in bed till paſt three a clock, ſlept out my dinner, and my ſtomacke will toule to ſupper afore fiue, therefore you muſt pardon me.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: Either ſee it all or none; for tis growne into a cuſtome at playes, if any one riſe (eſpecially of any faſhionable ſort) about what ſerious buſines ſoeuer, the reſt thinking it in diſlike of the play, tho he neuer thinks it, cry mew, by Ieſus vilde; and leaue the poore hartleſſe children to ſpeake their Epilogue to the emptie ſeates.
Why dooſt thinke thy audience like a flock of ſheepe, that one cannot leape ouer a hedge, but all the reſt will follow, they ha more of reaſon in them then ſo.
Well, Ile ſit out the play, and be but to auoyd that ſheepiſh imputation, but ſee it be baudy, or by this light I and all my friends will hiſſe.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: You ſhould not deale gentleman-like with vs els.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.l: The miſerie that waites vpon the pen
Of the beſt Writers, iudge it gentlemen,
Let them expreſſe the very ſoule of wit,
And want Opinions voice to countnance it,
Tis like the idle buzzing of a flie,
Heard, not regarded: wretched Poetrie:
If a write mirth, tis Rybaldry, and meane,
Scornd of chaſt eares. If he compoſe a Sceane
Of high writ Poeſie, fitting a true ſtage,
Tis counted fuſtian: If portick rage
Strike at abuſe, or ope the vaine of ſinne,
He is ſtraight inform'd againſt for libelling.
Neither quick mirth, inuectiue, nor high ſtate,
Can content all: ſuch is the boundleſſe hate
Of a confuſed Audience: Then we
That ſcarcely know the rules of Poeſie
Cannot ſcape check. Yet this our comfort is,
The wiſe will ſmile to heare th' impartiall hiſſ.
We neither bragge, nor tremble, faint nor intreat,
Our merrits nothing, yet our hopes are great,
Yet this our Author bad me boldly ſpeake,
His play ſhall paſſe, let Enuie ſwell and breake,
Detraction he ſcornes, honours the beſt,
Ta • ti for hate; thus low to all the reſt.

div.head: Actus primi. ſcena prima.
div.stage: ¶Enter Baſilius, Gynetia, Hipolita, Violetta, Lord attendants.

sp.speaker: Baſil:
sp.p: Welcom gallants, welcom honord bloods; the reaſon that we haue vncloth'd vs of our princely gouernment in Arcadia, and haue to doe with this priuate retirement heere in this defart Ile, you ſhall find in that ſhedule, onely thus much for publique ſatisfaction: Tis not ſtrange to you, that the choiſeſt treaſure Nature indow'd vs with, is mynde vp in the vaines of my two daughters: howe much their quiet, and the ſmothe ſtreame of our gouernment in Arcadia, was troubled by the impetuous concourſe of vnruly ſuters, is familiar with your knowledge; this to auoide, I haue for my Image there in my abſence appointed my brother, and vndertooke this priuate retirement.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Why my lord, are you ſo couetous of your daughters beauties, that their perfections ſhall be a meanes to hinder their preferment?

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Rather to further it faire Queene: they are the onely pearles of our age, and to ſee them well ſet in honourable and wel-befitting
sp.l: Marriage, is our wiſhes happines.
To which effect we haue ſent a generall challenge
To all the youthfull bloods of Affrica,
That whoſoeuer (borne of princely ſtem)
Dares foote the boſome of this deſart Ile,
(The ſtage where Ile performe this louers prize)
And by his wit and actiue pollicie,
Wooe, win, intice, or any way defeate
Me of my charge, my daughters of their harts,
Shall with their loues weare my imperiall crowne
Wreathe of their conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A prize, a prize, rare worke for Fencers.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What coward would not venter a crackt crowne for ſuch a bootie?

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.l: To that intent our Iland is fenc't in
By ſea and Land, and at each corner built
A Caſtle for defence, which like great men
Doe ouer-looke Archadea: ouer which,
We haue appointed Captaines. More to deſire,
Is more then we are willing to diſcouer.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well then ſiſter, I ſee we muſt to hap-hazard for husbands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: God ſend me one with a good face and I care not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Loue and be thy will, ſend mee one with a fayre table in his forhead, like Time.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Nay, and his face be good, let mee alone to tricke his forehead, a country-gentlewoman taught me how: But father I wonder how you dare vndertake ſuch a peremptory challenge againſt all cōmers, conſidering you haue beene ſo long troubled with an Ague.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: An ague? what ague?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: VVhy your quotidian, Dametas the Court ſurfet, hee that dwells in your eye, like a diſeaſe in your blood.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: And the Preſence were not exceeding empty-ſtomackt, it would neuer diſgeſt ſuch Almes-basket-ſcraps, the very fall & garbidge of gentry; fie vpon him, he becomes the great chamber worſe then a Gentleman-vſher with wry legges.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He is the moſt miſhapen ſute of gentility that euer the Court wore.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Had hee not beene of my fathers owne making, I ſhould ha condemnd his taylor for an exceeding botcher.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: If you retaine the loue of children, or the dutie of ſubiects, expreſſe it in your obedience, we know Dametas loues vs.

sp.speaker: Ʋilet.
sp.p: As Captaines and Courtiers do old widdowes, for profit and preferment.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: In ſigne whereof we make him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay, you haue beſtowed too much of the making of him vp already.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The very making of him vp, has ſtood you in more then the whole our ſides worth.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: In my free thoughts you wrong him, therefore to expreſſe our loue, and to giue the world publique note of his loyaltie, we create him your Gardian.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: How father, my Gardian.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: I mynion, yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Doe you heare father, bid him beſpeake Spectacles, for my fingers haue vowd to haue a blind match with his eyes.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Well ſaid Haggart, Ile make your proud hart ſtoope to the lure of obedience. But come, by this time our challenge is publiſht, and our gallants wits ſweating in the fielde of Inuention, and it behoues vs not to reſt vnexerciſed.
sp.l: So to our lodge, in the meane time be it knowne,
Our breath has power to raiſe, or caſt men downe.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Now Captaine Obſeruation, times bawde, thou that haſt kept the Ages doore, whilſt vp-ſtart baſenes crept into the bedde of greatneſſe, what dooſt thou thinke of this change?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: That it pleaſd the Duke, and becomes not ſubiects to examine his actions.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Thats no part of my meaning, yet would I gladly be better inſtructed why the Duke broke vp his Court in Archadea, and remoued it into this Iland?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: I am not Secretarie to his thoughts, but the generall mmour is, that out of the freenes of his ſpirit, hee hath ſent a challenge to all his neighbor Princes, that who ſoeuer (within a twelue month) can defeate him of his daughters, ſhall with theyr loues, inioy his dukedome, the garland propoſde for the victors.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
Your words throw ſence into mee, and thats the cauſe the Iland is ſo ſurely guarded with watch-towers, ouer which our ſelu ••
and other Captaines haue the charge.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap
sp.p: And to the end, that not affection, but deſart may prooue victor, are the two Ladies ſo narrowly obſerud, the one neuer out a the eye of her Father, the other continually in the lodge of Dametas, the Dukes chiefe director.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: If inquiſitiueneſſe be not too bolde a gueſt, what doe you thinke of Dametas.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: As of a little hillock, made great with others ruines.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Your compariſon holds, for by report, his auarice has vnmade many to make him vp.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: How did he firſt ſtumble on the Princes fauour?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: As ſome doe vpon offices, by fortune and flatterie, or as truth ſaies, the Prince hauing one day loſt his way, wandring in the woods found this Dametas, affected his diſcourſe, tooke him along to the Court, and like great men in loue with their owne dooings, countenanct his defects, gaue him offices, titles, and all the additions that g • e to the making vp of a man worſhipfull.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: I cannot but commend the Duke for rayſing him, nor yet praiſe him, that he proportions not his carriage aunſwerable to his fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Your thoughts and mine are twynnes in that: but I heare the warning bell, ſome ſtrangers are ariued.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p:
Lets to our office then, and conduct them to Dametas, whoſe cuſtome is to ſpet & hem, whilſt his ſcribe Maior takes they •
Examinations.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Manaſſes, how dooſt like my play at Tennys?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: You play well Sir, but you looſe ſtill.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Pollecie Manaſſes, pollicie, for when any man vpbraides me with my gettings at Court, I may ſweare trulie I haue loſt more then I haue got byte.

sp.speaker: Manaſ
sp.p: By the Tennis court I thinke you haue.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: If by any Court, tis enough to ſaue mine oath.
But what doe our ſpruce witted gallants ſay of my bounty.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Faith ſir according to the proportion of it, little or nothing they ſay tis a banckrout, and dares not ſhew his head.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p:
Then let em leaue reſting at me, though it pleaſe the Duke for ſome fewe good parts that he ſees in me, to make me his familiar,
I ſcorne to be publique, or euery Courtiers companion: but who comes heere?
sp.stage: Enter the two Captaines, with Aminter & Iulio two Princes, attyred one like a poore ſouldior, the other like a poore ſcholler.
sp.p: The Captaines of the watch-towers? what newes with you.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: A couple of peticioners, ant like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Had I beſt take theyr peticions Manaſſes?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O in any caſe, though you neuer peruſe em, tis the onelie courſe in requeſt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fellowes, deliuer your peticions to my ſcribe Maior, and doſt heare, put em vp Manaſſes, they may be wrongs to vs.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: And they be, I hope they be not the firſt wrongs I haue put vp for your worſhip.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: That fellowes pocket is like a Taylers hell, it eates vp part of euery mans due: tis an Executioner, and makes away more innocent petitions in one yeere, then a red-headed hang man cuts ropes in an age.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now, what are you ſirra?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: A poore ſouldier ant like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Poore ſouldiers doe not like my worſhip, they are bad members.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Then if they had a woman to their Iudge, they ſhould be ſure to be cut off, for they cannot indure badde members in a Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Iuiso.
sp.p: A poore ſcholler, ant like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Poore ſchollers doe not like our worſhip neither, they raile againſt rich Cormorants, they are bad members to.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Cut them off both ſir, and make the Land an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile take order with em I warrant thee, and I may haue my will, Ile ha neither poore ſcholler nor ſoldior about the Court.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: The next way to make it the Ile of fooles.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Whats he talkes of fooles there? why how now ſir, knowe you to whom you ſpeake?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Cry your worſhip mercy, I had forgot your authoritie.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
But I remember well enough I warrant you, I commaund you, in my name and the Dukes, to attend your gard, and you regard mee no more then a careleſſe Lawyer doth an vndone clyant,
but Ile informe: the Duke ſhall know, out, pack.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Commaund your ſlaues ſir, we are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why ſo I hope are wee ſir, and of the beſt and laſt edition, of the Dukes owne making.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Cry your authoritie mercy, will you diſcharge vs of theſe paſſengers?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: You are diſchargd, about your buſines.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Bad fate, that wrong ſhould ſet his foote on right, And true borne Eagles ſtoope to this baſe kyte.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What an excellent trade it is to be an officer maker, Ile haue more officers, and one ſhall be to keepe ſchollers and ſouldiers out of the Court, for they dare not come in the great Chamber alreadie, for want of good clothes. But gods me Manaſſes, goe tell the Duke I muſt ſpeake with him.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Preſently ſir, Ile go fetch the head to giue the foote a poſſet: and my maiſter had wit to his villanie, he would make an excellent diſh for the hangman.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Right worſhipfull.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I ſir, I knowe my place is worſhipfull, I tell thee knaue I could hang thee by my pattent, if it were granted once, Ile tell thee how it runnes, It allowes mee 24 knaues, 6 Kinghts, 10 fooles, 13 fellons, and 14 traytors by the yeere, take em howe, why, when, and where I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I doe not thinke the Duke will euer grant it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why not grant it? why ſhould you thinke he wil not grant it. Such another word & Ile ſend you to Limbo inſtanthe.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: We thanke you good Dametas.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: I hope youle take reaſonable baile for our forth-comming.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: The caſe is alterd with you ſince you came out of Archadea.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My honorable friends, Iulio and Aminter, my ſelfe and the beſt abilitie of my power, lies at your ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: You ſee how confidentlie wee preſume vpon your Letters promiſe, in furthering vs to attaine the louers prize.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The Dukes daughters are your owne, and in a word thus ſhall you attaine em, ſome 3 daies hence I will appoint a hunting, to which I will invite the Duke & both his daughters: in this hunt will I vpon ſome ſuddaine occaſion deuide the traine▪ and hauing ſingled out the two Does, I hope you haue wit enough to ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: To ſtrike, how meane you.

sp.speaker: Dametas.
sp.p: As headſmen doe, of with their maiden-heads, or if the Duke offer reſiſtance, of with his crowne to.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: That were violence, & cleane oppoſite to the intent of the challenge.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Come ye are ſhallow, too't vi et armis, too't, Ile be your ſecond, thinke of the crowne, ha my Letters trauaild for you, my wit wrought for you, and my inuention ſweat for you, to poſſeſſe you of your loues, and ſeate you in the Dukedome, & come you now with tis violence, and againſt the intent of the challenge, I am aſhamd to heare you.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Nay Dametas, and your reſolution be ſo forward, ours ſhal ouer-take you, wee doubted leaſt the preferments your Lord hath heapt vpon you, had ſmotherd your affection to vs ward.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: That was the father that begot the doubt in vs, you will appoint the hunt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Seuer the Duke, deuide the traine, and then.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Wee ha your meaning.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Put it in execution then, but firſt entertaine ſome new diſguiſe, as at our next meeting Ile informe you. Adiew, I ſhall thinke long till I ſee you agen.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: As a Lawyer doth for his clyant for a ſecond ſee. Heeres no Iudas?

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Yes, and a damnd one to, for hee would betray and ſell his Maiſter.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Tis common in ſuch baſe fellowes, ſuch Court-ſpyders, that weaue their webbes of flatterie in the eares of greatneſſe, if they can once entangle them in their quaint trecherie, they poyſen em ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: They are like vnneceſſarie wormes, whō the ſon of greatnes creates of the groſſe and ſlimie multitude, as ſoone as they recouer ſtrength, they eate into the credite of true borne gentrie, vndermine and worke out the true nobilitie, to inroote & eſtabliſh themſelues.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And in the end, like Eſops ſtaru'd ſnake, hauing lapt the ſweet milk of greatnes, made themſelues ſtrong in authoritie and friendes, they turne their ſtings of enuie into their preſeruers boſome.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
The example liues in this Dametas, who notwithſtanding the Duke hath raiſd him to that height that hee lookes equall with himſelfe, yet for the baſe hope of incertaine gouernment, hee offers him
to ſale, but let his treaſon liue to the laſt minute.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: For my part Ile make that vſe of him that Phiſitions do of poyſon, vſe as much of him as ſerues for mine honeſt intent, & caſt downe the reſt, as vnfit for any neceſſary imployment.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Let our carriage in this attempt put on no ſhow of violence either to the Duke, or his daughters.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: And let our diſcourſe goe ſo ſmoothly apparrelled, that it moue not the patience of the moſt tender eare.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: About it then, though his intent be baſe,
Our enterpriſe ſhall weare a noble face.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: Archadea, thou heauen, within whoſe ſpheare
The ſtarre that guides my motion is fixt,
I court thy gracious boſome with a kiſſe
For this admittance: in thine amorous armes
Faire Ʋioletta, fayrer then the flower
That chriſtned her, and grac't her with that name
Doe play the wanton:
Onely her Father like a couetous Churle,
Owner of that vnvalewed Diamond,
Hath made this deſart Ile th'vnwilling cheſt
In which he locks her. But the fayre aduantage
Of this large challenge, and my ſtarres to friend,
Ayded by this diſguiſe, I ſhall breake ope
His yron Casket, and inlarge my hope.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: This way ſhe went ſir, this way.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But I ſay this way, I would thou ſhouldſt know, we olde Courtiers can hunt a Cony, and put her to the ſqueake, & make her cry out like a young married wife of the firſt night.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.l: For more helpe, as ſome of them haue done,
But there ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ile vpon her preſently, dooſt heare me firra, thou veſſall of infirmitie, woman, and by thy out-ſide little better then one of the wicked, come hether and ſhow thy ſelfe before vs, ſhow thy ſelfe before Dametas.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: Dametas, Liſander then diſſemble,
For hee's the man muſt worke thy entrance.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What art thou, ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: My mother is the Queene of Amaſons,
My ſelfe a virgin, married vnto Armes
And bold archieuements, who haue pac'd the world
In queſt of fayre Autioste my ſiſter:
And turning homeward, the inconſtant windes
And wrathfull Neptune caſt me on this ſhore.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And whats your buſines now you are landed?

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: My buſines is priuate with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The Duke is buſie, and ſhall ſpeake with no body.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Tis no beſeeching matter I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: No, neuer beſeech for the matter, for except you could beſeech with the tongue of Angels, tis to no purpoſe with him.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Tis ſtrange, I haue heard thy maiſter is a very good man where he takes.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: True, where he takes he is, but hee takes nothing of you, and therefore looke for no kindneſſe from him.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Good, and dooſt thou take after thy maiſter?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No madam, I take commonly afore my maiſter, for where he takes, he takes all, and leaues nothing for me to take.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Oh, I feele your meaning.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let my maiſter haue ſome feeling of yours, and heele preſet your ſute.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Tis not the Dukes pleaſure Peticioners ſhould buy theyr acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Als one, tis my maiſters pleaſure, and vſuall faſhion.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And I muſt maintaine the faſhion. Worſhipfull Dametas, my late ſhipwrack as you ſee, hath made a defeate both of my friends and treaſure, notwithſtanding, Fortune hath reſeru'd me one Iewell, which if I might requeſt your worſhippe in loue to accept, and be a meanes to worke my admittance to the Duke, I ſhould become a true detter to your loue.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: VVell Madam, tho I hate nothing more then a man that takes brybes, yet preſt by your importunitie, and that you tender it in loue, leaſt I might ſeeme too nice to withſtand a Ladies fauour, Ile weare it for your ſake, and if the Duke be not too buſily imployd, worke your acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: So dooing, you ſhall performe the office of a dere-bought friend.

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: How quickly the tyde's turnde, but doe you heare Madam, tho I take neither afore nor after my Maiſter, yet take my counſell, & doe not truſt my maiſter: If you haue a ſute to the Duke keepe it to your ſelfe, for if you truſt my maiſter with it, heele prefer it for you, but heele begd for himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Thats plaine cooſnage.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.p: Fie no, tis cunning in him, marry twould bee though little better then cooſnage in a country gentleman: but he returnes.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Madam, I haue beene earneſt, very earneſt with the Duke for your admittance.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And haue you wrought it?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I haue, marry you muſt thinke I beſtowd much labor int.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Tmay be you did.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Tmay be you did: & looke a ſeance like a Pothecaries wife pounding Colliquintida, haue my braines ſweat for this.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: VVhy the Iewell is right Dametas, had I but an Aſſe that would ſweat me ſuch pearle.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: An Aſle? and ſweat ſuch pearle, Ile bar her admittance, heere take your Iewell, the Duke will allow no admittance, & I will keepe you backe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Keepe mee backe, thou couldſt doe no more and I were a poore mans peticioner.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And Ile doe ſo much beeing a rich peticioner.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: You cannot ſir. You Court ſpaniell, you vnneceſſarie muſhrump, that in one night art ſprung out of the roote of greatnes, I haue bought my admittance, and Ile hate in dſpetto del fato.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I muſt admit her, theſe Ladies are ſo inward with our tricks, theres no good to be done vppon them: well Madam, your admittance is open, will ye follow.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: With all my hart ſir, Ile be the blind man and poore peticioner, and thou ſhalt play the Court ſpaniell with the ſiluer bell, & I cad me into the Preſence.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Court ſpaniell? mum: Ile boſome what I thinke,
Old Gibs not blind, I ſee altho I winke.

div.stage: Enter Demetrias a Prince, attyred like a wood-man, with him his Page.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Boy, how dooſt like me in this attyre?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: As the audience doe a bad play, ſcuruely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is it not ſtrange a prince ſhould be thus metamorphoſed?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Not ſo ſtrange as the metamorphoſis of Aiax and like your grace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Grace you Aggot: haſt not forgot that yet?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: No, and yet tis a wonder I ha not, grace beeing ſo fildome vſde, Ime ſure they ſay none at ſome Ordenaries, for at ſitting down they cannot intend it for hunger, and at riſing vp, they are either drunke, or haue ſuch mind a dice, they neuer remembe •• , my Lord then.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: No more Lord, ſirra.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Indeede there are many already, but is not this ſtrange, that rich men ſhould forſake their titles? maiſter then.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Your will ſir.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: You have left many Countries behind you in ſeeking your friend Liſander, and yet you cannot find him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: True ſir.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I ha ſeene much golde lying vppon Lombards ſtalls, and could neuer finger penny of it.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Nay, twas not well ſir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What conclude you then?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: That you were beſt ſit downe, and ſee what you ha got by your iourney.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I haue ſeene a face as beautifull as heauen.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Thats nothing, a priſoner ſees the face of heauen it ſelfe, when hee lookes but out at the priſon-gate, Ile ſtand roote, a man were as good be hangd, ſo a meet a handſome hangman, & a ſtrong rope, as be in loue.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Your reaſon for that.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Mary this ſir, hanging is end of all troubles, & loue the beginning. Nay further, I think a Lo • d cannot be ſau'd, for hee is of all religions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your proofe for that.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: This; hee thinks with the Atheiſt theres no GOD but his Miſtris, with the Infidel no heauen but her ſmiles, with the papiſt no purgatory but her frownes, & with the familie of loue, hold it lawfull to lie with her, though ſhe be another mans wife.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So ſir, what followes?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Seruing men ſir, the Maiſter goes in before his wife, & the ſeruingman followes his maiſter.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Syrra forbeare, I muſt meditate.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: As the Vſurer before he parts with mony, meditate vppon the aſſurance.

div.stage: Enter Liſander priuately, and ouer-heares them.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l:
I •
Ʋiolettaes preſence ha not quencht
The memory of all things but herſelfe,
I ſhould be more familiar with that fate.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I haue left my country to ſeeke out my friend.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: And I my country and my friend for loue.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: And in the ſearch of him haue loſt my ſelfe
In the ſtrange Region of a womans eye.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: In loue, and in Archadea.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: As much as heauen tranſcends the humble earth,
So towres her praiſe, her face differs as farre
From others, as a glo worme from a ſtarre.
She is a princeſſe that my ſoule affects.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And rich.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Halfe heyre vnto this Dukedome.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: And ſhee were whole heyre to the foure morrall Vertues, twere nothing: when ſhall I ſee the time that men will loue for vertue, or a rich h • yre marry a poore wench without a portion, neuer I thinke.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Had not my friend Liſander.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: What of me?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: L 〈…〉 nt in Thrace.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.l: We had neuer met in loue,
His ſillables betray him. I arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: At whoſe ſute.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Not at his Taylers in any caſe, for theres no greater ſtitch to a younger brothers conſcience, then to pay for a ſute of appariell when tis worne out.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Liſander or his ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: Demetrius,
Or ſome illuſiue tenant in his ſhape.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Vnkind, why didſt thou leaue my company?

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.l: For that which made the amorous Gods leaue heauen,
For loue: but why is Demetrius thus diſguiſd?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: For that which would make a lackanapes a Monkey, and he could get it: a tayle.

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: Peace rogue.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Why wagge, is thy maiſter in loue?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p:
Faith ſir he hath entred his action in Cupids court, & meanes
to proceede in the ſute it ſhou'd ſeeme.

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: Why didſt not take my counſell in thy choiſe?

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Becauſe I feard a chiding, for doubting thine honourable thoughts would not haue conſented to my effeminate attempts, I ſtole this ſecret courſe, and manner of diſguiſe, as beſt helping to acceſſe, which it hath begot, now what acceſſe will bring forth, I commit to vnborne Induſtry.

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: It cannot but be proſperous: onely the ſtrict obſeruance of our loues, hinders the paſſage of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Indeed thats not the leaſt hinderance, yet the Duke himſelfe, and my quaint diſguiſe hath remoued it out of my way, who not onely takes mee for a woman, but hath allowd mee for my loues companion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Fortune deales kindly with thee, I am as farre from acceſſe to my loue, as when I was in Thrate.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Dametas is the oyſterſhell that holdes thy pearle, our vvits muſt fiſh for him.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: VVill the Cods head byte?

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p:
Like an old Vſurer at a young heyres inhe •• tance, and I h'ate ready hookt for him: and he ere he comes, my plot is to preferr •
thee to his ſeruice.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Prethe doe, and Ile ſerue him in his right kind.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Dametas, my loue is yours.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: VVhich madam I am as proud of

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: As a malecontent of a change, or an old Lady of a new faſhion.

sp.speaker: Li:
sp.p: To be roūd I haue a ſute to you in the behalfe of this woodman

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: To me ſweet bloſſom, tho I be ſomwhat ſtrict in mine office, I cannot be ſtony to Ladies. Fellow is thy petition drawne?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Peticion.

sp.speaker: Manaſ:
sp.p: Your onely way to mooue a 〈◊〉 by: Humbly complayning to your good worſhip, O tis moſt pathetick, and indeed without money, can doe iuſt nothing with authoritie.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Come hether ſtripling whoſe ſonne wert thou?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p:
I am not ſo wiſe a child as you take me for, I neuer knew •
my father.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Didſt not know thy father?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: A common fault, his betters forget themſelues whē they grow rich, then blame not him to forget his father.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: VVhat was his name?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: If I may giue credite to my mother, they cald him Menalchas, who on his death-bed made mee his heyre, with this charge, to ſeeke your worſhips ſeruice, & gaue me this gold as a remembrance to purchaſe your fauour.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Gold him?

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.p: Now doth my Maiſter long more to finger that gold, then a young girle married to an old man, dooth to runne her husband? aſhore at Cuckolds hauen.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Well, I could doe for this fatherleſſe youth.

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.p: As many Executors and Ouerſeers haue doone, cheate him of his portion, and then turne him out of doores a begging.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: But for I haue the gardian ſhip of the Prince, I dare doe nothing without the conſent of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Come come ſir, your worſhip ſhall not refuſe him.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Well then I wo not, but tis for your ſake I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Meaning the gold.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What ſhall I call thy name?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Dorus ant like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ah, good Dorus, be an honeſt youth Dorus, reuerence your Maiſter, and loue your ſelfe: be ſure to get vnder me, and you ſhall looſe nothing in my ſeruice. Madam, the Duke and Dutches expect you at the hunt, & await your comming at Dianaes oake.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Ile attend them preſently, be a good ſeruaunt Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Twill be his owne another day Madam.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: In the meane time let it be yours to lead the way.

sp.speaker: Dametas
sp.p: My ſeruice doth attend you,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As the Purſeuant doth the priſoner for a double fee.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: Welcome ſlaue to a ſlaue, a fayre preſage,
The hope of loue ſweetens loues vaſſalage.

div.stage: Enter Aminter and Iulio, attyred like Satyres.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: Now & Dametas be the mettle he was ſtampt for, a right villaine.

sp.speaker: Iulio
sp.p: And he be not, hang him.

sp.speaker: Am:
sp.p: Nay he deſerues hanging to if he bee: but wil you truſt him?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p:
Yes as farre as I ſee him, and hee that truſts him further my
truſt is he will be deceiud.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: Indeede, he that will proue falſe to his maker, wil be true to no man.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Yes for the preſent time, like a bawde to him that giues moſt.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: Thats not for loue.

sp.speaker: Iul:
sp.p: Yes of the mony: he that lookes for other loue in this age. This is the place his Letter ſpeakes of, and here he comes himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Why ſo lo: now is the web of my hopes vpon the loombe of perfection, and in this quech of laſhes Aminter and Iulio.
sp.l: See and ſee not, all mum, you know your que,
The games your owne, if you can hunt it true.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Dametas, were thine eares euer at a more muſicall banquet? how the hounds mouthes like bells are tuned one vnder another like a ſlothfulnes, the ſpeed of the cry out-ran my ſence of hearing.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Croſſe ouer the Forreſt to Dianas oake my liedge, & there your grace advantagde by the height of the ground, ſhall not onelie at pleaſure heare, but be eye-witnes of their muſicall contention.

sp.speaker: Baſ.
sp.p: Thanks good Dametas, be thy directions our wiues conuoy.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Where is his highnes Dametas?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: At Adonis bower Madam, where he expects your preſence to ſee the fleſhing of a couple of Spartane hounds, in the waſting blood of the ſpent Deare.

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.p: Thankes good Dametas, mine eyes would not be good friends with my feete, ſhould they not bring em to that kingly ſport.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Sweet Ladies, to ſaue you the expence of much breath▪ which muſt be laid out in the purchaſe of the game. I haue prouided you this ſtand, from whence your eyes may be commaunders of the ſport: ſuch ſport as you little dreame of.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol:
sp.l: We are your loues detters kind Dametas.
As I loue vertue I pittie theſe poore beaſtes,
Theſe Syluane comoners, to ſee what taskes
Our couetous Forreſters impoſe vpon them,
Who not content with impoſt of their breath,
(Poore harts,) purſue them ſmiling to their death.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Twas the end of their creation Madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: So was the end of ours to liue in peace,
And not to tyranniſe on harmeleſſe beaſtes,
But Forreſters, like Images ſet forth
The tyrannie of greatneſſe without pittie,
As they the Deare, ſo couetous wealth purſues
The trembling ſtate of their inferiors.
And to claſpe vp the volume of their ſinnes,
They drinke theyr blood, and clothe them with their skinnes,
Then ceaſe to preſſe poore beaſts with tyrannie,
You loue your liues, thinke they are loth to die.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: You are too tender-harted to be a good huntſwoman lady.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: And ſome of you too hard-harted, but leauing this diſcourſe of hunting, haue all our gallantry of Lacedemon and Greece, ſpent the vigor of their wits, that not one dares venter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: For our loues ſiſter, you may ſee the properer women, the worſe lucke.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Tuſh you ſhall haue ſuters, feare not madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No at any hand ſiſter, for with a feare it comes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then Ile feare of purpoſe, becauſe I would haue em come.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And they doe not, they are notable cowards.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Then let em keepe away ſtill, for I haue vowed my maiden-head ſhall neuer doe homage to the bed of a coward.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Sweet Ladies, will you beguile a minute or two with this diſcourſe, till I ſtep vp to the top of the hill, and make diſcouerie of the game,

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Let your returne be ſpeedy good Dametas.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Ile put on wings and flie.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Out of the Court, and the whole Country ſhall haue a good riddance.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: So, hee hath put em faire to the ſtand, lets iſſue and ſurpriſe them,

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: Be reſolute and ſuddaine.

div.stage: Aminter and Iulio, iſſue out and beare them away.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Murther, treaſon, reskue, helpe.

div.stage: Enter firſt Dametas, and then the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Yes much reskewe, much helpe, much Dametas: why ſo, this leſt was drawn home cloſe to the head, it cannot chuſe but cleaue the very white of our hopes, the Dukes wit • to thy tackle good wit, ſome ſuddaine ſea roome, or our ſtratagem is run a ground.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p:
Tell me Dametas, was not the Deare a prodigall, did he not
ſpend his breath freely amongſt vs?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And his blood too my liege, but did you obſerue how the hounds like politicians noſd out the game?

sp.speaker: Ba
sp.p: True: & comming to the loſſe Melampus, but where are our daughters?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Did you obſerue that my liege, that Melampus as a true hound is euer horce cheerd or hollow, yet he kept time to.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Certaine Dametas, but where are our daughters man?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Buſie my Lord vnder a brake buſh, diſputing of the vertue of ſweet water, and ground Iuie.

div.stage: Cry within, treaſon, murder, reskew, helpe.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: VVhat cry of treaſons that Dametas?
Pray God no danger ſets vpon my daughters,
Seeke out our wife, Ile haſt vnto their reskue.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And my ſworde vn-imployd? allegeance: ſayes nay to that my Liege, I am for the aduenture my ſelfe, if they bee ſurpriſd (I am a mad man) your grace ſhall heare more: If not ( 〈◊〉 the more ſorrie) your grace ſhal heare more to: make peace with your thoughts till my returne, and doubt not their recouery.

div.stage: Enter the Duches with her daughters, Dametrius, Liſander. &c.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Speake, where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.l: Heere my Genitia.
What meane theſe weapons, are our daughters ſafe?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: As a thiefe in a 〈…〉 ill father, we thanke our redeemers.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The more my griefe, were you ſurpriſd then madam?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes ſayth Dametas.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And how ſweet Ladies, and how were you reskewd?

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.l: Beeing ſurpriſd, this gallant Amaſon
Preſt to their reskew, had you ſeene what worth
She and this woodman ſpent in our defence,
Wonder would ha bereft you of all ſence.
She raiſde her ſword with ſuch a manly grace,
As had nor her mild ſexe-contrould my thoughts,
I could haue falne in loue with her high worth.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.l: You ouer price vs madam, not our deſe ••
But the weake ſpi 〈…〉 of our oppoſites.
Gaue leiſter to the di 〈…〉 nes of our worth.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.l: It pleaſe your modeſty to lesſon it.
But it ſhall ſtill liue great in our regard. What woodmans that?

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: My follower my Liege.

sp.speaker: Baſil:
sp.l: VVhat ere he be, he hath deſeru'd our loue.
Fellow be neere vs, and for this deſert,
Performd againſt thoſe Traytors to our blood,
Vnder thy maiſter we giue thee an attendant,
To garde the life and ſafetie of our daughter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Thanke you good father, who euer looſe by the bargaine, I ha got me a ſeruant by the match: wot ſerue me fellow?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: In the beſt I can.
In hart your fellow, though in ſhow your man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Ile try your du • ious ſeruice: I command,
Your knee to kiſſe the ground, your lip my hand.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam.

sp.speaker: Hippol.
sp.l: Heeres hote loue no doubt,
I may commaund my man, and goe without.

sp.speaker: Baſil:
sp.l: Truce to this ayrie warre, theſe paper bullets
Better become a Cloſſet then a Parke,
The Forreſt muſick is to heare the hounds
Rend the thin ayre, and with a luſtie cry
Awake the drowſie Eccho, and confound
Their perfect language in a mingled ſound,
Then ſo the Court, our Forreſt ſport beeing done,
A ſecond chace o • louelier ſport's begunne.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: If fortune croſſe not what our hopes purſue,
Our feares haue met theyr deaths, our loues theyr due.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Croſt in my hopes, the Ladies reskewd, and the Princes like crauens beate out of the game-place, my inuention muſt turne trauailer for more ſtratagems • what & I ſhould diſcouer their plot to the Duke, attach em for traytors, and begge their lands for my labour; though they be my friends, twere a pretty parcell of pollicie.
sp.l: All things are lawfull that doe profit bring,
A wiſe-mans bow goes with a two-fold ſtring.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p:
Did euer two princes meete ſuch ſtrange changes in their loues? now we haue wrought our admittance, and in a manner got
em into our poſſeſsions, ou • hopes like falſe fires hauing brought vs within • en, vaniſh, and leaue vs out of all comfort.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: That the duke ſhould doate vpon thee for a woman, makes for our purpoſe, but that the dutches ſhould be enamourd on thee for a man, is prepoſtrous.

sp.speaker: Laſan.
sp.p: VVhether my 〈◊〉 ſh • wne in the reskue of the Ladyes, or the ardent glances her daughters beauty ſteales from mine eyes, giue her thoughts incouragement, I know not, but her hopes ſtand confident I am a man, & for that cauſe am I bard from acceſſe.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: I way thy co 〈…〉 rances by mine owne, for tho by the Dukes allowance I am her priuiledged attendant, yet ſuch is the deuiliſhnes of Dametas, that I cannot ioy ſo much acceſſe as to confer with her.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I can compare my lord and his friend to nothing in the world ſo fitly as to a couple of water buckets, for whilſt hope winds the one vp, diſpaire plunges the other downe, whilſt I like a Harl • kene in an Italian comedy, ſtand making faces at both their follies.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: VVell, ſince the ſhape of our proceeding growes ſo monſtrous, lets caſt our inuentions in a new mold, and hauing ſo firme a foundation as this diſguiſe to build vpon, lets draw the modell, and raiſe the whole frame of our attempts anew.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Indeede, louers ſhould be conditiond like tyrants, who hauing the ayme of a crowne in 〈…〉 violently ouer all lets that intervent their courſe, and ſo muſt we.

sp.speaker: Liſan
sp.p: And ſo will wee, my reſolutions already bent, & if I ſhoote not, the next leuell I take, 〈…〉 I beſeech thee breake thy bow about mine eares, and ſtrike the hornes in my forhead, for married men to hang their caps on.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: I haue met a meanes 〈◊〉 my purpoſe already: Mopſa Dametas onely daughter, is 〈…〉 in loue with me, & to her Ile faine extreame ardor of affection, and make her the ſhadowe vnder which Ile court the true ſubſtance of my deuine Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: About it then, Ile ſweat my inuention to death but Ile ouertake thee; but heere comes one of my 〈◊〉 . I muſt heare his importunitie, for no reaſonable deniall will bruſh him of.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Zehnane.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: My Liedge.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p:
My thoughts come like a ſaile afore the wind, ſwolne big with newes and thine eares the midwife muſt deliuer me of this burthen,
my Dutches is ſick, hart ſicke for thee Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: For mee, why my Lord, I am no Roſaſolis, nor Aqua mirabilis to recouer ſicke folkes.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Shall I be ſhort with thee? My Ladie's in loue with thee.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: With me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: With thee my Lady: her amorous glances are her accuſers, her very lookes write Sonnets in thy cōmendations, ſhee carues thee at boord, and cannot ſleepe for dreaming on thee in bedde, ſhee's turnd ſunne-riſer, haunts priuate walkes, & like a diſgraſt Courtier, ſtudies the Art of melancholy.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Now alas good Lady.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Nay neuer pitty her, ſhe deſerues none, rather lets bend our indeuors to intangle her more. To ſee the kindnes of Fortune, who fearing we ſhould be acquainted with ſollitude in this our 12 month retirement, hath begot a domeſticall merriment, and made our own thoughts actors int, and as bad a Poet as I am, Ile ha one ſceane int of mine owne inuention.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Dametas will ſtorme at that, for he cannot indure Poetrie ſhould be countnanſt: but how iſt my Liege?

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Tis ready plotted already, and that the Dutches may not find thee vnprouided when ſhe comes to court thee

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Court me, court a woman my Liedge.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: VVhy thats the very happineſſe of the ieſt, but in any caſe confeſſe thy ſelfe a man.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: A man my liedge, I ha no colour fort.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Tuſh Ile furniſh thee, ſay thou art ſome Prince, no matter who, & haſt to do with this diſguiſe of purpoſe to court my daughter Violetta,

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Is this ſceane of your owne inuenting my liege?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Mine owne yfaith, and to confirmt the rather, vſe more oft & priuate conference with my daughter, interchange diſcourſe & amorous dalliance, oh twill ſet my Dutches affections a flre, to thinke her riuald by her daughter, and giue vs ſmooth paſſage to our loue.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: How occaſion plaies the wanton with me. Well my liedge, do but you worke my admittance to your daughter, & Ile beſtow al the art I am woorth in courting her, and ſee, as if Fortune had a hand in our Comedy, ſhe hath entred the Dutches iuſt at her que, ſhadowe your ſelfe in your Arke, & leaue me to giue her entertainement.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Forget not to perſonate ſome Prince in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Ile warrant you, Ile play the Prince with much art.

sp.speaker: Dutches.
sp.l: This way he went, on this ſweet violet bed
Still dwells the print of his enamourd tread,
The depreſt flowers haue ſtrengthened their ſweete
By ſtealing amorous kiſſes from his feete.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Abſolute Poet, Penelope was a ballet-maker to her.

sp.speaker: Dute.
sp.l: Oh do not fli • my preſence, gentle wanton ſtay,
What haue I found you, faith you run-away
Ile tye a chaine about your waſt for this,
And make you buy your freedome with a kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Fie madam, this curteſie is more then needes▪

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Be not ſo coy, let not a louing Dame
Find thee leſſe kind then ſenceleſſe elements,
Thou neuer walkſt, but the enamourd ayre
Like an officious louer beares thy traine,
Whilſt the coole wind doth with his veluet wing
Fanne the thinne ayre vpon thy ſweatie cheeke,
Stealing ſweet kiſſes from thy ſilken lip.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Shield this vaine breath, beate at ſome ladies eare.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: But you are none, you are not, come you are not,
Your valor, lookes, and geſture ſhew you are not,
Your manly brow, and your commaunding eye,
Where war and fortune dwell in maieſtie,
Your priuate walkes, and varied paſsions,
Your glances to my daughter, ſure you are not,
And my firme loue is confident you are not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: There's a louer of a right temper, ſheele outface the name of her ſexe inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well madam, ſith your obſeruation hath diſcouerd mee, vpon promiſe of your ſecreſie I confeſſe my ſelfe a man.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Good, excellent, how truly ſhe takes my directions.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I knew my iudgement could not be deceiud,
Nor durſt proud loue haue done me ſo much wrong
To caſt my thoughts vnto a womans eye.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Loue durſt not, good, good, excellent, what next.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: But madam, now I am knowne to you, what further requeſt you.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Exchange of lookes, and freedome of thy bed,
Thy preſence, thy embracements, thy kind loue,
For which my amorous thoughts haue long line ſicke.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Thanke you good wife, nay & a Dutches long to giue her husbands the horning, let it neuer greeue butchers to doe homage at Cuekolds hauen.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Well madam, to giue content to your affections, and in a ſtrong hope you will mediate my ſute to your daughter, ſort out but fit time and opportunitie, and maiſter your deſires.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: And he were a man now I might be rarely tupt.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Giue me thy hand then, with this amorous kiſſe I ſeale thee mine.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And I confirmt with this.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.p: Rare, rare, rare, ſhe's his ſeald and deliuerd in the preſence of her husband.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Now leaſt my husband ſhould ſuſpect our loue,

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Now, what ſhadow for that now.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Heare a good ieſt, perſwade him th'art a woman.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Thats not to doe now madam, for he as confidently belieues and ardently courts me for a woman, as you for a man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Good, excellent, maintaine that humor ſtill,
Seeme coy, looke nice, and as we weomen vſe,
Be mild and proud, imbrace, and yet refuſe.

sp.speaker: Baſil.
sp.p: Excellent vertues in a woman.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I prethe doe, twill be a ſceane of mirth
For me to quote his paſsions and his ſmiles,
His amorous hauiour, and how his eye
Will beget ſtrange varietie of lookes.
And ſhoote em into thine, but the cheefe ſports this
To ſee an old man with a young man kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.l: To ſee an old Dutches a young Lady kiſse.
Now the plot packs the ſceanes all comicall,
I cannot ſpeake for laughter, to ſee theſe women
That would be counted wonders for their wit,
Lay plots to gull themſelues, ſilly conceit,

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: To take me for a man.

sp.speaker: Baſi.
sp.l: And arme herſelfe
To laugh at me, make ieſts and ſcoffes at me,
But ſooth her humor, the reuenge ſheede throw
Vpon my head, ſhall fall on her owne brow.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p:
Vpon you both, ſo, ſo, ſo, how greedily their inuentions like bugles followes the ſent of their own gullery, yet theſe are no fooles,
God forbid, not they: but to the drift, mirth in my warme blood ſits, laughing at this diuiſion of theyr wits.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Wot te beleeue me ſiſter, I neuer eate a cherry, but it puts me in mind of a husband, it kiſſes my lippes with ſuch a harmleſſe prettines.

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.p: Now in good deede lo I loue em a life to, I thinke I ſhall neuer ha my belly full on em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Of what, not of husbands Violetta.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: No, of cherries Hipolita, but take heede of em, they be a ver • e filling meate, and dangerous things for vs maides I can tell you, wee may ſurfet after em preſently.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Surfet after what, a husband?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I and after cherries to Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I warrant you ſiſter, an old lady in Lacedemon taught mee a preſeruatiue againſt that.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: For the loue of cherries what.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Marry this it was, ſtil ſayd ſhe, betwixt euery cherry ſaid ſhee, be ſure to cracke a ſtone ſaid ſhe.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Then let me alone, Ile cracke a couple a ſtones betwixt euerie cherry, rather then ſurfet on em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You muſt take heede you cracke not too many to, for you may ſurfet of the ſtone as well as of the cherry.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: Nay & they be ſuch dangerous things, I haue done with em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: So haue I to for this time, but ſiſter, is it not a ſtrange kind of ſeruile libertie that we liue in heere in Archadea?

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.p: For all the world as Engliſhmen keepe their fellons, & Italians their wines, we neuer ſtirre abroad without our Iaylors.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And for what cauſe forſooth, onely to keep vs frō mariage.

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.p: Sure tis eyther ſome high content, or extreame diſcommoditie, that our father debarrs vs of it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: By this ſtone me thinks I long like a woman with child, till I know the difference betwixt a maid and a wife.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Well, god a mercy of all curſen ſoules, I was neere the knowledge ont laſt night I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O that I had beene with thee I might ha beene ſo to: for loue of marriage how?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: VVhy thus: as I lay ſlumbering in my bed,
No creature with me but my maydenhead:

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is that a creature?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Some maintaine it is.
Got in the eye, conceiued in a kiſſe:
Others whoſe ſpeech ſeeme neere akin to truth
Say tis a paſsion, bred ith heate of youth,
Some callt a ſigh, and ſome an amorous grone,
All differ in the definition,
But in the allowd opinion of moſt,
Tis neuer truly had till it be loſt.
But lying thus alone, as maydes doe vſe,
Me thought I dreampt, as maydes can hardly chuſe,
And in my dreame me thought twas too much wrong
A prettie maid ſhould lie alone ſo long:
With that a gallant comes, gallants can doe
Much with young maydes,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And with old women to.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.l: He couted me once, and agen, and thrice,
Tis vertue to ſay nay, to be too nice
Agrees not with my humor, yet ſome ſay,
We maydes wiſh things, to which we aunſwere nay,
Breefely me thought he ſtood ſo long a wooing,
I rather could a wiſht he had beene dooing
Some other buſines, yet at laſt we greed,
Twere ſtrange if earneſt ſuters ſhould not ſpeede.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: In what agreed you?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: In our wedding ring,
Time, place, and howre, indeede in euery thing:
The day appointed, and each thing in frame,
I thought each howre an age vntill it came,
VVell, come it is, the morning once in ſight,
I thought it tenne times longer till twas night.
At dinner time me thought I ſweld with pride
To be drunke to by name of Miſtris bride,
Muſicke ſpake loude, no delicates were ſcant,
Yet ſtill me thought another thing did want,
For ſure thought I, theres ſomething in a man
That wiues loue well, hope brides may wiſh it than.
Long lookt for comes at laſt, to bed we goe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Would I had dreampt I might ha done ſo to.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My bed-mate turnd, and as he would ha ſpoke
I ſwe • t with feare, and in that feare I woke,
But ſeeing my kind bed-fellow was gone,
Lord how it chaft me that I wakt ſo ſoone,
One minuts dreaming longer, I had tride,
The difference twixt a virgin and a bride.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O twould ha vext a ſaint, my blood would burne
To be ſo neere, and miſſe ſo good a turne.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: And ſo did mine to I warrant you, nay tho I be but a little pot, I ſhall be as ſoone hote as another.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You ſhould not be my ſiſter elſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: Nor my mothers daughter neither.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And in good earneſt we are not fatherd much amis.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Are you aui • d of that, and yfaith tell me, what thinke you of your ſeruant Dorus.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: As of a ſweet Almond in a rugged ſhell, the ſun in a clowde, or a welthy diamond in a rock, indeede cleane contrary to the world, he weares the worſt ſide outward, & is much better then he ſeemes: but what thinke you of your manly Amazon.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: Nay the ſport is I know not what to thinke, Zelmanes humor would afford proiect for a prettie Court comedie, my father courts her for a woman, and as I feare ſhee is, my mother doares vppon her for a man, and as I wiſh he were, and that with ſuch an ardor of affection, that I could find in my hart to turne my mother out of the companie, and play the louers part my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: How euer man or woman, the ieſt holds currant in one.

sp.speaker: Ʋio.
sp.p: I knowe not what knauiſh motion hath had to doe with my thought, but my mind tells me that your ſeruant Dorus & my Amazon, are other then they ſeeme: and heere he comes.

div.stage: Enter firſt Liſander, then Miſo, Mopſa, Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Why how now madam, Ladies gadding, is this the obedience of your fathers charge.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Pardon Miſtris Miſo, twas my dooing and the Dukes.

sp.speaker: Miſo
sp.p: But the Dutches w • l like neither the Dukes doings nor yours neither in this caſe I can tell you. The Duke ſtaies your comming & yet the dutches is very deſirous ont, my husbands is in the next Arbor to man you. For you Lady, my preſence be your priuiledge.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Miſo ſhould be either a hangman or a Herald, for ſhee neuer
comes amongſt vs, but ſhe quarters our company and armes.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Excellent beautie, & therefore more excellent, becauſe ſituate in ſo faire a creature.

sp.speaker: Mopſ.
sp.p: You are a merry man Dorus, but all this cannot make me think you loue me, how ſay you mother doth he.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Mary let him choſe daughter, when I was as thou art.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You were as ſhe is, but faith madam Mopſa, I perceiue my ſeruant Dorus beares a months mind to you, be not ſo ſtraight laced to him. Mop. Straight lac'd, ſgod mend me I am not lac'd at all, am I Dorus, no in ſoth, I goe wide ope wenſday, I neuer lace my ſelfe but on ſondaies, & that for feare I ſhould burſt with eating of plum porridge. Hip. I mean let fall ſome comfortable lookes on your ſuter.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: ſgod mend mee Ile let fall or take vp any thing I haue to doe him good.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why thats kindly ſaid, & Dorus your loue is verie ambitious, to climbe ſo hie as the beautifull Mopſa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: O are you aviſd of that, twold make a horſe breake his bridle to heare how the youth of the village will commend me, oh the pretie little pincking nyes of Mopſa ſaies one, oh the fine flat lippes of Mopſa ſaies another, and then doe I bridle my head like a malt-horſe thus, ſet mine armes a kembo thus, wrethe my necke and my bodie thus, winke with one eye thus, & ſpread my peacocks tayle as broad as the proudeſt minx of em all.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Theſe extraordinary graces muſt not want admiration, but where's your mother.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Speake ſoftly in the Lobby there, for waking my Ladies foiſting hound.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Godſme, my mothers ſtealing of a nap.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay, ſhe cannot be ſaid to ſteale a nap, for the noiſe ſhe makes herſelfe would diſcouer her theft: but Dorus ſith your fortunes are poore, you ſhould ſtudie to enoble your deſerts, and beget effects worthy to court and win your Ladies acceptance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Laſſe madam, I chuſe no better moderater then your ſelfe, betwixt me and my vnworthy ſeruices, ſuppoſe your ſelfe tho but a Cucko compard with this ſweet ſinging Nitingale, ſhould be ſued to by a prince like me, I meane like me in loue, for loue in princes & peſants admits cōpariſon: ſuppoſe Demetrius ſhould in like diſguiſe court you as I doe, Mopſa, ſigh for you, as I doe, for Mopſa, kneele to you thus, as I doe, to Mopſa, lay downe his life to you, as I doe, to Mopſa, prefer your good before his owne, as I proteſt I do, Mopſaes, ſuppoſe he ſhould ſhow you the known marke of his neck, to aſſure
you he were Demetrius, as I do this to Mopſa, to witnes I am the ſon of Menalchas, could your diſdaine ſtand out like Mopſaes?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What a kenes neceſsity ſets vpon the edge of inuention, truſt me Mopſa your ſeruant ſpeakes wel, & if he can proue himſelfe the man he ſpeakes of, and my wiſhes wel hope, Demetrius, you haue no reaſon to thinke ſcorne of him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Why what ſhould I do madam, my mother tells me I muſt not ſay as I think.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I am no counſeller, but ſhold Demetrius in like diſguiſe court me, thus would I imbrace him, thus ſeale my affections with a kiſſe, & thus argue: think not Demetrius that the clowds of baſenes could ſo muffle thee, but that the ſun of valor ſhind thro them long ſince, & in regard of thy ſeruiceable dutie in concealing, and vnpre • ented policy in thus making known thy loue, ſort but out fit oportunity, & in deſpight of all gardians ſtrict obſeruance, go where thou wilt, the worth of Demetrius ſhall draw Hippolita, this would I vow, and this will I performe.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: And were I Demetrius & you Hippolita, I would deciue Dametas, outreach Miſo, forſweare Mopſa, & forſake Archadea to ſhare the fortunes of diuine Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And what ſhould I doe then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I do but ſpeake in the perſon of Demetrius, & vnder Hippolita ſhadow what I intend to the rare, and neuer enough wondred at Mopſa, the black ſwan of beauty, & madg-howled of admiration.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Do not you flout me Dorus, & you do not, prouide a prieſt and Ile marry you, and my father and mother ſhal neuer know one.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Manaſſes is the man.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And Ile be the woman, who ſo euer ſay nay toote, little dreames my mother of what wee haue done.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Tmay be ſhe did, for ſhe ſigh'd & grond much in her ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Tis wel ſhe was ſo quiet, for ſhe eate peaſe poridge to breakfaſt, & theyle make me break wind in my ſleepe like a horſe, and ſee as the deuil wil hate ſhe wakes, and here comes my father, no words and ye loue me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why god a mercy Dorus, this dilligence becomes the ſeruaunt of Dametas, and Ile prefer thee fort.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You were worſe then the deuil els, for they ſay hee helps his ſeruants, then you may doe little & you cannot helpe yours.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Will you break your ieſts againſt the barres of you chamber windowe, & cleere the greene, the duke is comming to bowles, & I would not for halfe mine office you ſhold be a rub in the way of his
pacience: Daughter and Wife, conduct her to the Lodge. Exit. And Dorus. make you haſte about your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: I warrant you Sir: be my hopes rightly plaſt?
You will condemne me for my too much haſte.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: Why ſo: this tis to be in authoritie: Inferiour perſons, I and the Princes themſelues, flie from my preſence, like the chirping Birdes from the ſight of the Faulcon: my verie breath like a mighty wind blowes away inferiour Officers (the Court rubbiſh) out of my way, and giues me a ſmooth paſſage: I am the morning ſtarre, I am ſeldome ſeene but about the riſing of the Sunne: indeede I am neuer out of the Dukes eye; and heere he comes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Doth our match hold.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Yes, whoſe part will you take.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Zelmanes.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Soft, that match is yet to make.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Lets caſt a choice, the neereſt two take one.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My choice is caſt, helpe ſweet occaſion.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Come, heere's a good.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well, betterd.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The Duke and I.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: The weakeſt goe to the wall.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Ile lead.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ile follow.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: We haue both one mind.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: In leauing the old folke behinde.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Well ieſted daughter, and you lead not faire,
The hindmoſt hound, though old, may catch the hate.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Your laſt Boule come?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: By the faith a me, well led,

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Would I might lead you,

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: To my bed.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: I am ſure you would not?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: By this aire I would.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: I hope you would not hurt me, and you ſhould.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I'de loue you ſweet.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Sowre, ſo I heard you ſay.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Accept it then.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Of what acquaintance pray?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Of loues, and mine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Daughter, your bowle winnes one.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: None of my Maidenhead Father, I am gone,
The Amaſon hath wonne one.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Yeeld to that.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: The caſt I doe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Nay ſcrape out that.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Whoſe is it yet?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: The Dukes: play ſmooth and fine,
The ſmalleſt helpe that is, will make your mine.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Me yours?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Your mine, for tho the caſt I looſe,
I ha wonne your loue.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Much: in my tother hooſe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Come, the laſt market this caſt is worth all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The leader as the follower.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.l: Badd's the beſt,
I winne her for ten crownes, and there they be.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: I take your lay.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A match twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Ile be your halfe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: That were vnkindly done.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Pardon me mother, Ile beare all or none.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I ha wonne you Madam.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I meane your bet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then take your winnings, ile not die in debt.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Madam beleeue me, I am as I proteſt, a Prince, my name Liſander.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Looke to the Dukes ſtanding Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: So I will I warrant you, and to your falling.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p:
Thus clouded as you ſee, for your loue, my ſoule ſpeakes in my tongue: I appointed this match at bowles a purpoſe to acquaint
you with it.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Barre ſtealing Father; yet and all hit right,
Heer's one would ſteale a piece of fleſh to night.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Deere Madam.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: No more words, I haue perceiued as much in your eie, as you can expreſſe with your tongue, and as farre as my mothers ielouſie would giue me leaue, anſwered it with kind lookes: your bias ſtands wrong mother.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Why? It ſtands towards Zelmanes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Hath it ſtood ſo long?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: All the game thro.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Then all your game's bold wrong: furniſh you with neceſſaries befitting an eſcape, & my wil ſhal be as ready to take wing, as yours; put in a caſt now mother, or the game is gone indeede.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Whoſe is the throw?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ours, till the laſt bowle came.
But that hath wont'em cleere, both caſt and game.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Our winnings come, a kiſſe and bate the reſt.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: What doe you kiſſe in earneſt or in ieſt?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In earneſt in good trueth.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Troth, kindly ſed,
Take heed you kiſſe not out your maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: In ieaſt?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: In earneſt.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.l: Tis the faſhion,
Much in requeſt among our Nation.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: To kiſſe away their maidenheads?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now and then,
And being gone, to kiſſe it backe agen:
For louers indentures are nea're fairely drawne,
Vntill the maidenhead be left in pawne,
As earneſt of the match, ſo mothers ſed,
And ſo will daughters do when Mams be dead.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What? pawne their maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Yes, and looſe'em too.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And youle maintaine that faſhion?

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Signeor Noe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Lay by this homebred mirth, and prepare your eares to entertaine ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Stranger? why Father, Strangers are as welcome to mee, as mine owne Countrymen; if they bring good manners, & ciuill humanitie in their companie: otherwiſe, they are like foule weather, come afore they be ſent for.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p:
Dometas, nay then we ſhall haue newes enough; for he neuer comes into the Preſence, but he brings a whole ſacke full of
〈…〉 es: of newes I ſhould ſay.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Welcome Dametas: what officious fellow is that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A pure welwiller of your Maieſties, & a follower of mine.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: O tis Manaſſes; and he could make Armes aſwel as he mars Legges, he would grow in great requeſt for Heraldrie: What's your newes?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Theſe Lacedemonians, Subiectes to your Maieſtie, hauing a Meſſadge to deliuer to your Maieſties inſtruments of hearing, commonly eclipt, eares.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: How? Hath any one heere, clipt eares?

sp.speaker: Manaſ.
sp.p: Sweete Femenine, clip off the taile of thy diſcourſe with the Siſſars of attention, as I ſay, theſe Lacedemonians haue choſen me their tongue.

sp.speaker: Ʋiol.
sp.p: Of a long tongue thou ſpeakſt verie little.

sp.speaker: Mana.
sp.p: That proues me no woman, for they ſpeake ouer much.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: What greuances oppreſſe them? briefly ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Marchandiſe (my Ledge) through the auarice of purchaſing Officers, is rackt with ſuch vnmercifull Impoſt, that the very name of Traffique growes odious euen to the profeſſor.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Townes ſo oppreſt for want of wonted and naturall libertie, as that the natiue Inhabitants ſeeme Slaues, & the Forrayners free Denizens.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Offices ſo bought and ſould, that before the purchaſer can be ſayd to be placed in his Office, he is againe by his couetous Patrone diſplac't.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Common Riots, Rapes, and wilfull Homicide in great mens followers, not onely, not puniſhed, but in a manner countenaunced and aplauded.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Indeede ſince your Maieſtie left the Land, the whole bodie of the Common-wealth runnes cleane againſt the byas of true and priſtine gouernement.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: And your honorable Brother, like a Shipp toſte vpon the violent billowes of this Inſurrection, by vs intreates your Maieſties Letters of ſpeedy reformation, for feare the whole kingdome ſuffer ineuitable ſhipwracke.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Which after ſhort deliberation with our Counſell, your ſelfe ſhall returne. Dametas, rewarde their trauayles with 200. Crownes: in the meane time, let'em taſte the beſt entertainment of our Court.
sp.l: Proud Rebels, they ſhall ſee that a Dukes frowne,
Can at his pleaſure, turne Rebellion downe:
See them rewar • ed.

sp.speaker: A 〈…〉 i.
sp.p: Manaſses, ſee the fellowes entertaind; I muſt attende of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Boy, ſee the fellowes entertaind? I muſt waite of my lord.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fellowes, be as merrie as you may, I muſt follow my M.

sp.speaker: Ami.
Juli.
sp.p: Well Cupid, pray for our liues, for and we were gone, I know not where thou wouldſt haue two ſuch ſtateſmen againe.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: His Common-wealth could not ſtand without vs: and that his Mother knowes well enough: and he ſends no better ſucceſſe then we had at our hunting, hee looſes a friend of mee.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: T'will not ſinke in my thought yet, but that olde muſtie ſlaue Dametas playde the ſlaue with vs.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Would I could prooue it once: but ſince we are againe admitted our Realme, ſhall wee be idle? ſomewhat weele doe, though theyle giue vs but ſmall thankes for our labour.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
