sp.p: The Duke ſhall not ſay his Daughters are ſo ill beloued, but weele change a thruſt or two with his intent for'em.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: T'would put the poore Wenches out of conceit with themſelues, and there ſhould not be ſome contending for'em.

sp.speaker: Jui.
sp.p: We are in the way to catch the old one, and then our ayme deceiues not.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: We are I faith: Inuention could not weaue,
A quainter webbe, Suſpition to deceaue.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p:
Come, paſſe off this groueling imitation; a Louers
thoughts muſt be ambitious, and like the Eagle, ſcorning the bace ayre where Kites and Crowes lie flagging: mount the cleare skie of Inuention, & ouerpeere al hindrances:
sp.l: The Ladyes themſelues are willing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ready to imbark vpō the next tide of occaſion whatſoeuer.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Let me alone to worke it then. But heere comes my Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: T'were more for your credite Sir, and you could ſay your man: but men & warr were worne out of faſhion both in a Sōmer.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: I am of thy beliefe in that, Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Would my Lord were ſo to, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Suppoſe I were Sir what then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſhould (as many vpſtartes haue done) prooue rich: for I beleeue you would make mee your heire.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Is that part of your beliefe?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A principall poynt Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Renounce it then, for I beleeue you'le neuer beſaud by't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am ſure I cannot looſe by't. I beleeue further, that many Knights, and ſome Ladyes, were neuer of Gods making.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Of whoſe then, wagge?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ile tell you: the Minters quoine Gold, Gold makes Heralds, Heralds make Nnights, and Knights ſtampe Ladies.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: And what doe Ladies?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They liue not idlie neither; they make ſome Knights, and marre manie Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Ladyes are good worke-women too, then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Farre better then anie Taylor: they'le make you an ende of a ſuite, eſpecially a Court ſuite, when all the Taylors in a Countrey know not how to ſet a ſtitch in't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am of the beliefe you are a Knaue, Sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I had no ſayth, ſhould I ſay you were not.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Well, what, a Knaue?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In a Knaues beliefe Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Becauſe in yours?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Do you ſay't, and Ile ſwere't, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No more Boy, I am wearie of your ieſtes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That coufirmes'em to be good Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your reaſon for that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Becauſe trauellers and louers, are ſoone wearie of goodnes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Goodlie ones in deed: but leauing this high-way of circumſtaunce; I ſent you for Manaſſes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The learned Scribe attendes you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Will you fall off, Sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Like an Apple at Michaelmas, without ſhaking.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Welcome Manaſſas: I haue preſent imployment for thee, in which I muſt borrow

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pardon mee Madame, I learned of my Lord, to lende nothing without ſecuritie and pawnes.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: T'is not monie (Manaſses) but counſell and furtherance that we deſire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good counſell is worth good monie, Madame.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt be well conſidered; there's twentie Crownes in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay Madame, this hand's like a fellow, it takes euerie thing in ieſt; if you be in earneſt, let me feele it heere: So Ladie, now betwixt earneſt and ieſt, if your Will be readie drawne, before your friend deliuer'd as your deed, and put me in truſt to execute it.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Tak't, in a word this honeſt Shepheard, and thy Lordes daughter Madame Mopſa, are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Man, an woman perhaps; but not man and wife: for though moſt women haue a wil to be Ladies, like my Lords wife; yet euerie Ladie haue not witte to be a wife, as my Lordes Daughter. But what good can I doe in this?

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: O verie much: for though they be man and wife by oath and proteſtation, the chiefeſt ceremonie of all; namelie Mariadge, is yet vnperformed, and hearing that you haue tane orders.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That I haue: I haue tane order for the making away of a hundred Maidenheads in my time, and not ſo few: but I am in in the minde of you now, theſe two Beagles, Dorus and Mopſ • , haue run themſelues breathleſſe in the chaſe of loue, you would ha me couple'm vp in the leaſes of Matrimonie.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Manaſs.
sp.p: And you in the wrong, Ile keepe your ieaſt, but in any caſe take backe againe your earneſt: ile not purchaſe my Lords diſpleaſure with your gold.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Thy Lord ſhall neuer know't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh ſir! though my M. hath but bad eyes, he hath exceeding long eares: and though a Forrayner may play with a Citizens wooden Dagger, I would not wiſh any to ieſt with a Courtiers ſteeld Sword; tis ſeldome drawne but it drawes blood.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Tuſh man, be not ſo timerous, my credit ſhall countenance thee: bee not an Aſſe, make vſe of thy time: thy Maiſters ſeruice is no heritage; the world knowes he gettes vnder the Duke, thou art a foole, and thou wilt looſe vnder him: there's a hundred Crownes for thee; tuſh man, thy betters will ſtraine curtſey with aleagence for a bribe.

sp.speaker: Mana.
sp.p: Madam, could you to euery one of theſe Crownes giue me a Kingdome,

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Man.
Liſa.
sp.p: Soone in the euening at Adonis Chapell. Art reſolute?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As your Adamant: thinke you t'was feare made me keepe out? no t'was hope of theſe flattering ſweete lipt drabs, I feare to marrie my Ladyes daughter? no nor to go to bed with her neither. Why, I haue counterfaited his hand & ſeale. He has been content with mee, to come nearer to him, at his entertainment of the laſt Embaſſadour, when he was heat with drinking of healthes. As I led him to his Chamber, I nimde his Chayne, and drew his Purſe, and next morning perſwaded him he loſt it in the great Chamber at the Reuels. He puts mee in truſt with his whole eſtate: he buyes Maners, I purchaſe Farmes: he buildes houſes, I plucke downe Churches: he gets of the Duke, and I of the Commons: he beggers the Court, and I begger the whole Countrey.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Theſe are notable knauiſh courſes. What breeding haſt had?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Verie good breeding Sir: My great Graundfather was a Rat-catcher, my Grandſier a Hangman, my Father a Promooter, and my ſelfe an Informer.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Thou wert a Knaue by inheritaunce.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
And by education too: but Bawdie Informations growing ſtale, I gaue vp my cloake to a Broker, and crept into credite for a Gowne, and of Manaſſes a penurious Informer, I turned
Coppie, & became Manaſses, a moſt, preciſe, & illiterate expoſitor.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Were you a Reader then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And a Writer too Bullie; I ſet ſome of my Pariſhioners Wiues ſuch Coppies, as their Husbands might caſt their cappes at it, but could neuer come neare.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But and you vſde ſuch a high and eleuate ſtile, your auditories low and humble vnderſtandings ſhould neuer crall ouer't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Tuſh I could faſhion the bodie, of my diſcourſe fit to the eare of my auditorre: for to caſt Eloquence amongſt a companie of Stinctards, is all one as if a man ſhould ſcatter Pearle amongſt the hoggiſh animals ecliped Swine: no I had paraphraſticall admonitions of all ſortes; Some againſt couetous Landlordes, and that would I ſquirt awongſt beggerlie Tennants: Some againſt Vſurers, and that would I throw in at Priſon Grates amongſt prodigall Banqeoutes: Some againſt the pride of the Court, and that honies the eare of the Citizen: Some againſt the fraude of the Citie, and that's Cake and Cheeſe to the Countrie: Some againſt Proteſtants, and that's plumpes the laſie Catholicke againſt Papiſt and Proteſtant, and that fattens the rancke witted Puritand, againſt Papiſt, Puritand, and Proteſtant; and that tickles the eare of the luxur ous Atheiſt.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Why you neuer light vpon anie Atheiſtes, doe you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Oh verie manie.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: In the Countrie perhaps, and the out-skirtes of the citie?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: In the verie booſome of the Citie: and by your leaue, heere and there one in the Court too: But wee fi • t 'em all; for in deed wee wandering Lightes, haue (as other tradeſmen haue) Commodities of all ſortes, and priſes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: How doe they come by them?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As manie doe by Offices, ſteale into them ere the Duke be aware of 'em.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Some buy'em at Booke-ſellers ſtalles; but the beſt they beſpeake of Poets.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Mee thinkes Poets of all men, ſhould not edifie, they are ſo enuious.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
One to another, to no bodie elſe: a proud Poet is for all the world like a Puncke in requeſt, couetous of manie Cliantes, when ſhe hath more then ſhe can handſomely play off: You
ſhall haue ſome Poet (Apolloes Vicar, eſpecially) write you a comicall, Paſtorall, Tragicall, Muſicall hiſtorie in proſe, will make the auditors eyes runne a water like ſo many waterſpouts: I had one of them my ſelfe, and your eares be in caſe, Ile giue you a taſte on't; his argument was fet out of the Poem called, The loſt ſheepe: and thus it is.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Pre'thee be briefe?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay peace, and it were in place where you might wake, the beſt men in the parish, for commonlie they ſleepe the beginning, becauſe they loue not deuiſion: but to the loſt Sheepe. Beloud, you muſt imagine this Sheepe was a Sheepe, a loſt Sheepe; a Sheepe out a the way: but my deare flocke and louing Sheepe, whom like a carefull Shepheard, I haue gathered together with the whiſtle or pipe, as it were of mine eloquence, into this ſold of peacefull Communitie; Doe not you ſtray doe not you flie out, doe not you wander, doe not you looſe your ſelues; but like kinde Sheepe, and valiant Rams: I ſpeake to you the better part and head of my flocke. As I ſay, you ſhall ſee the valiant Rammes turne all their hornes together, and appoſe themſelues againſt the Woolfe, the hungrie Woolfe, the gredie Woolfe, the Lams-deuowring Woolfe, the Woolfe of all Woolfes, to defende their Eawes and young ones. Durſt you ſay all your heades together, and with the hornes of your Manhood defende your families, your owne wiues, and your neighbours children: Was not this ſtinging geere?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A good Sheepiſh admonition.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The fitter for my Audience: while you liue, haue a eare to fitte your Audience.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Thou ſpeak'ſt like a Chriſtian: prethee what Religion art of?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How manie ſouer I make vſe of, Ile anſwere with Piauano Orllotto the Italian: I profeſſe the Dukes onely.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: What's his reaſon for that?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A very ſound reaſon: for ſayes hee, I came Raw into the world, and I would not willinglie go roſted out, ſo cloſe vp the ſtomacke of your Diſcourſe with that dry anſwere, and euey man about his buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You'le be mindfull of to morrow-night.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: As your Lawyer of the Tearme, or your Landlord of the Quarter day.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why ſo: the mettle I muſt forge my plot on, lies a warming in the furnace of my braine; and I muſt faſhion it Inſtantly, for feare it burſt the heat. Giue my conceit way, for heere comes one muſt helpe to proportion it.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: How now Demetrius, what winde hath blowne vp this ſtorme of melancholie, thy countenaunce was not wont to be thus cloudie? Whence proceedes this ſodaine alteration?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: From mine owne hard fortune my Lord, that my ill-ſtard natiuitie ſhould continue thus oppoſite.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Art croſt in a ſute at Court? or what's the matter? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ile acquaint your Honor: I hope no other eare ouerheares vs, Vnder Dianaes Oke I founde an inſcription vpon a ſtone, which told me, that wealth Ariſtomeres ſometimes brought into Archa lea, had there vnder hid a maſsie ſumme of treaſure.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Vnder Dianaes Oke? Dorus ſhall haue my daughter Mopſa: no more words on't, and thou loueſt me Dorus: ſmother thy golden hops a day or two; thou ſhalt haue Mopſa, but Ile haue all the Gold, then marie my daughter to ſome great man, though he be poore, tis the faſhion: Ile be Noblie allied what ere it coſt me: ſhalt be my Sonne in law Dorus: haue an eye to the Princeſſe, fall cloſe to my daughter Mopſa,
sp.l: Court her and ſpare not: now begins the ſport,
Kiſſe her, doe kiſſe her; thou ſhalt pay ſweetly fort:
I can gull you, know what faire words can doe,
I'me an old Knaue, and a young Courtier too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So, ſo; how violently he deuowers his bane, and ſteales himſelfe into the order of Gullerie: mee thinkes I ſee how betwixt hope and feare he ſweates in his practiſe, and like a fooliſh dreamer, caſtes how to lay out his wealth before it comes in. So much for him: Now to my Ladie Beautie his wife; and as the Diuell would ha're, heere ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Dorus, how now Dorus' What time a day is't with you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What time a day ſo'ert be with mee, tis ſleeping time with my Lord, I'am ſure of that.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Sleeping time Dorus, what doſt thou meane by that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay nothing: he is troubld with a kind of maladie cald Iuſurectio carnis.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: How, a diſh of Creuices? nay and that be the worſt, good enough: I am glad a falles to Fiſh, for he was giuen to Fleſh a late too too bad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Maſſe I thought as much, for I ſaw him go a angling.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: I hold my Ladiſhip to ſome ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Life, a ieloſie; I thinke you are a Witch, t'was ſo indeed.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: Nay I thought as much: he was wont to kiſſe mee, and doe all kindnes a man could doe, till he came to the Court; and nowe hee will not lie with mee forſooth: and why? tis the Court faſhion. He will not loue mee, and why? tis the Court faſhion. I muſt not come neere him at his downe lying, nor his vpriſing, ctc. And this be the Court faſhion, would I were an honeſt woman of the Countrie againe, be Courtiers who liſt. I, I, Dorus, I tell thee in teares, hee hath not done by mee, as a Huſband ſhould doe.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Tis nothing to mee, I cannot do withall Madam, would I could.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Yes marie mayſt thou Dorus; thou mayſt, and ſhalt doe withal too and thou wilt: but as thou lookeſt to enioy my daughter Mopſa, acquaint mee with the olde Foxes ſtarting hole.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's paſt my cunning: the olde Foxe has more holes then one, to hide's head in: But not to goe long about the buſh with you.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: No good Dorus, I do not loue a man ſhould go long about my buſh: What is ſhe for a woman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
Miſo.
sp.p: Manaſſes wife? marie fire Maiſter gunner; a Putitane turnd Puncke: Gods my precious. Ile ſlit her noſe, as I am a Ladie will I: is shee the partie you wot on?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes fayth Madam, shee is the Mare the man rid on.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Ile ſpoile their ſport, ſadle my Mule there, haue an eie to the princeſſe: ſhalt ha my daughter and be but to ſpite him withal, faith Fox ile ha you out of your hole, or ile fire you out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay that will doe no good, but for your owne good Madam, take heed you doe not ſcold.

sp.speaker: Miſe.
sp.p: Why may not a Lady ſcold Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Scold, O in no caſe, twill marre a Ladies beautie cleane, and make her looke as hard fauoured at any ordinarie woman.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Godamercie for that Dorus, Ile not looſe my beautie for twentie on'em: ſaddle my Mule, bring me my chopping knife, Ile gold the lecherous Goat, and mince his Trull, as ſmall as herbs to the pot. This is not ſcolding Dorus, is't?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No this is tollerable.

sp.speaker: Miſ.
sp.p: Nay then I care not, ſaddle my Mule I ſay, let her pray God her feeling be good, for as I am a Ladie, Ile not leaue her an ele to ſee withall, and yet I will not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh take heed of that at any hand, So, ſo, ſo: now it begins to quicken me thinkes, I ſee alreadie how ſhe runs atilt at the Wenches eies: cals the maid Baud, the woman Whore, and her husband Lecher: and when all comes to all, like an Iriſh Wolfe, ſhe barkes at her owne ſhadow; but committing her and her Aſſe to their wildgooſe chaſe: now to my ſweet hart Mopſa, for she's all the blockes laſt in my eie to ſlumble on: and God bleſſe my wits, for the foole haunts me.

sp.speaker: Mopſ.
sp.p: Dorus, where's my Father Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your Father, Oh my deare Mopſa?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay now you flout me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Flout you? oh the faire heauens, but this ti's for a man to caſt away himſelfe in violence of paſsion and extremitie of ſighs on a piece of beautie, that cares not for him, but it is the tricks on you all.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Trickes, no as god mend me, and I should not haue a huſband till I got him with tricks, I should lead apes in hell: but faith tell me, doſt thou loue me Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Doe I loue you quoth ye, It cuts my very heart ſtrings, doe I loue you? why tis the onely marke my Inqeuors she or at.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: If thou doſt not hit the marke, then thou'rt a very bungler: but where is my Father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why I haue ſent him and your mother out of the way of purpoſe, and appointed Manaſſes to meet vs this euening at Adonis Chappell in the Amaſons apparell, to marrie vs: I thinke this are ſignes I loue you.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I but you ieaſt, I doubt you will not marrie me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will you meere me there?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I am a Virgin I will.

sp.speaker: Dor,
sp.p: And come with an intent to marrie me?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I hope to be a wife I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You muſt take heed you keepe our purpoſe cloſe,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I did the loſſe of my Maydenhead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why haue you loſt it then?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Many a deere day agoe, yet I told Nobody on't but my Mother and our Horſekeeper, and they ſay I am nere the worſe mayd for that, and I can keepe my owne counſell, as I hope I ſhal; but will you meet me ſoone?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Iuſt in the mid-way, as Tilters doe.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Ile goe afore and ſtay, but doe not deceiue me, and you doe, Ile ſhew my Fathers Horſekeeper all as God mend me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So tria ſequntur tria, now am I rid of a triumuirie of fooles,
and by there abſence haue won a free acceſle to an eſcape.
If my Liſanders hope proue like to this,
This night ſhall Crowne vs Monarchers of our bl ••• e.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No more of theſe delayes ſweet Madam, your loue hath broken day oft with my expectance, I dare giue it truſt no longer.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: I confeſſe it my Liege, and like a ſpent Deare, not able to maintaine longer flight, I caſt my ſelfe downe breathleſſe at your loues mercie: yet I beſeech your Maieſtie, let not your eager deſires, practiſe any preſent violence vpon my yeelding chaſtitie: twas onely poſſeſsion of my loue you had in chace, which with conuenent time & place purchaſed, I put your grace in full poſſeſsion of.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
Although thy Breath be neuer but Muſicall, yet it neuer taught the ſtring of true happines till now: and to approue thy
heart ſets hand to thy word, appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Then this preſent euening (and yet my Virgin blood, and aſhamd to conſent to the betraying of my modeſtie) meete me at Adonis bower, where ile make tender of ſubdued chaſtetie to your high Maieſtie, as my firſt & moſt victoriuos conquerour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By my Imperiall Globe, and hope of thoſe Ioyes, thy preſence ſhall bring to inrich me with, ile meete thee, and make thee Queene ouer the moſt ſubmiſſe Captiue that euer loue tooke priſoner.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: If you deceiue me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not except warme life,
Deceiue my voice of their innatiue heate.
Then haſt ſlow time, exchange thy leaden ſleete,
For Hormes wings till I my faire hopes meete.
But lockt once in the armes of my delight,
Cloth all the world in an eternall night.
And ſteed of morning when the Sunne ſhould riſe,
They ſhall ſee two in my Zelmanes eies.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.l: So farewell thought I, I haue prepar'd you a Zelmanes anſwerable to your expectation.
Then triumph in thy will, and let thy thoughts
Proclaime a lubilee: my teeming hope:
Are now deliuered of a gratious birth,
Which I haue Chriſtened, opportunitie.
Vnto whoſe ſhrine in honour of this day,
My thoughts ſhall hold a monthly ſacrifice,
Loue graunt Demetrius, meete the like ſucceſſe,
Our paines are crownd with double happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Onely our diſguiſes hold firme, but all other attempts meete vntimely deathes, euen in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: What and wee ſhould acquaint the Ladies with our intents.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p:
Twould argue a kind of cowardiſe in out wits, that ha ſuch ſuſpectles admittance to there preſence, as this diſguiſe hath purchaſed vs, we should not haue that abilitie of inuenture to entangle'em
in their owne ſecuritie.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Well howſoeuer, we muſt not dwell long determining for the libertie of ſtay with Dametas, who out of his couetous diſpoſition in detaining our reward, allowed vs the eldeſt day of our licent abode at Court, is run out.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Tis very true, and for my part, Ile rather go home with a priuate repulſe, then managing any vnlikely attempt, become ſufferer vnder a publike diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Ami
sp.p: Thats my very thought, yet that our ſecond ariuall bee not altogether empty of imploiment, lets practiſe ſomething vpon Dametas, and acquaint the world with his coward baſenes; in which, he not only detracts from his maſters bountie, but looke how as Conduit head or maſter-ſpring that is poiſoned, doth his beſt, to enfect the whole bodie of the court, with the leproſie of his couetouſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Theres no action of his begetting can be ſaid to be truely honourable.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: How can they when there Father's a mungrell, the Duke out of his honourable bountie commaunded him to reward our trauailes with 200. Crownes: and now after two moneths attendance, and enforſt delayes: In which time an ordenarie petitioner might haue ſpent the vaſew of the reward, he packes vs off with 50. Crownes, his excuſe being that his maſter hath forgot vs, and what he doth, is of his owne bountie, as if the Moone ſhould brag ſhe gaue the world light, when al the luſter she hath, comes from the heat of the Sunne.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Should his villanies be ſuffered to proſper, they would grow to ſuch height, as the Dukes authoritie should ha much trouble to prune them.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: To preuent which, his maieſtie shall haue priuate note of it, knew we in whoſe truſt to conduct it.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: Tis an Office verie few dare vndertake, he is ſo riueted to the Dukes good opinion.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: Lyes there no iarre twixt none of the Nobilitie and him, what ſay you Zelmanes?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: The gallant, Amaſon: you could not ha caſt your choyce fitter, for her honorable minde maintaines deadly feud againſt his bace proceedinges: and heere she comes, attended by Dametas ſeruant, lets waite on oportunitie.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Liſander.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Iulo.
sp.p: Liſander and Demetrius, ſtand cloſe, of my life we are come to the birth of ſome notable knauery.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: How blowes the winds of our hopes?

sp.speaker: Liſand.
sp.p: Fayr to the point of our expectlicion, I haue made away the Duke and the Dutch.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How made away them? poyſond them.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: with a confection of loue, which I haue ſo tempred with fair promices, as theyr minds are in loues heauen already: Ʋidelicet in Adonis bower, wher this euening I haue giuen em my word to meet em; but I haue ſo caſt it, that Manaſſes ſhall meete em in my ſteede.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Twil be a rare ſcean of myrth, to hear what coſtly diſcours the ile beſtow vpon the foole in thy outſide.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Do you heare that.

sp.speaker: Ilipo.
sp.p: yes, thanke loue and my eares, but liſt the concluſion.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: I haue cleard the way to Violetta, but what order haſt thou tane, with thy burbolts: Dameta, Myſo, and amorous Mopſo.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: ſhot em away, at three ſeuerall markes, yet ſo conueyd it that in the end they ſhall all meet at Adonis chappell.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: This proiect cannot but bring forth ſome notable deceipt.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: My hopes ſhould want of thyer will, and it do not.

sp.speaker: Liſand.
sp.p: Now we haue made a ſmooth paſſage to our eſcape, how ſhall conuey our louer out of the Iland.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I haue determined of that ſir, and better to effect, my boy this time haſt caſt ſuch a bait of knauery to the two Captaines, Kalader and Philinax, as we may paſſe without ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: But how for tranſportation.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I am furniſht of that to, you remember the two Lacedemou intelligencers

sp.speaker: Ilip.
sp.p: Now what of vs.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: Hold my life, we ſhall be put in this ſcean of gullery.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: Oh in any caſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: For the loue of Cupid do, iniquiris paſt, lets take our entrance, and paſſe ouer the ſtage like mu • es, to furniſh out a ſhowe.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p:
And ſee occaſion like a kind wench preſents em in the very inſtant my honeſt friends welcome, haue you not your diſpatch
with a letter to Lacedemon.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: Madam we haue, and ſtay onely to take our leaues of your Ladiſhip, and know what ſeruice your honor will command.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: you haue my thankes, for the truth is, I muſt commit buſineſſe of much import vnto your truſt, and to preuent much circumſtances take my word, you are not ignorant of the Kings generall challenge.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: About his daughters.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: you vnderſtand me, with theſe few crowns receiue my mind which is to conuey the 2, ladies whome we in theſe diſguiſes haue woon to Lacedemon,

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: were we but confirmd of your of eſtates.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: wele giue your ſufficient aſſurance of that and the princeſſes themſelues ſhall confirme it.

sp.speaker: Iulio,
sp.p: we craue no better madam, but ſhall we not ha yours honors company.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: No: hauing brought them abord, weele make returne to the Duke, to let him vnderſtand we ſtole not our prizes but woon them manfully at the point of wit.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: A noble reſolution.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.p: His foile wil appeare the more palpable, and your conqueſt the more applauſable, where ſhall we receiue the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Be that our care, but on your liues be heedful of your ſafe ties.

sp.speaker: Amt,
sp.p: More then of our own my lord,

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Inough whilſt you attend weele to the Duke, and play all guls or none.

sp.speaker: Iulio.
sp.l: All Guls indeed ſince you had follies whip,
No guls, to all guls, fooles loue fellowſhip.

sp.speaker: miſo.
sp.p: Looke well to mine Aſſe ther, lord how I ſweat with anger; this ſames the houſe ſure, and now like a wiſe Lady let me count my hurts, and ſee how I ſhal be reuengd: it ſhalbe ſo, ile haue em both carted, and manaſſes ſhal go afore like a whifler and make way with his horns, where be theſe whores: open the dore, wher be theſe pan ders: O that I were not a lady: I could ſcold like a butter-whore,

sp.speaker: wife.
sp.p: whoſe there a gods name, lord for his mercy is the woman mad.

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: yes I thanke ye fort: horn mad, wheres your companion whetes the old leacherous goat my husband, open the doore I ſay.

sp.speaker: wife.
sp.p: Ieſus for thy mercie ſake madam, what do I want.

sp.speaker: Miſo.
sp.p: what do I want, the chiefe implement a woman ſhold haue I want that as a woman cannot be without, I mean my husband, I want.

sp.speaker: wife,
sp.p: your husband, I ſawe him not as I am an honeſt woman.

sp.speaker: mi.
sp.p: not as you are an honeſt, ſo I think, but as you are an arrant whore you did, you muſt haue your Creuiſhes with a pox cannot Citty Maunchet and freſh cod-ſerue your turne, but you muſt haue Court cake-bread and Creuiſhes with a vengeance, but come giue me my husband, or ile haue him out of the fleſh on thee, and yet I will not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: Pray Madam ha patience: what ſhould your husband do here

sp.speaker: miſ.
sp.p: That which he ſhould do at home with his wife, and he were worth his eares.

sp.speaker: wife,
sp.p: Lady I proteſt I do not know him,

sp.speaker: miſo.
sp.p: Not know him thou lieſt in euery vaine ith hart thou lyeſt, thou knoweſt him, and as Adam knew Eue thou knoweſt him, hee hath bene as inward with thee, as euer he was with me, he hath by his own confeſſion he hath, & thou denieſt it, thou lieſt in thy throat like a Puritanicall whore as thou art, O that I were a butter-whore for an houre I might ſcold alittle.

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: Madam they are no honeſt men that bring theſe tales to you

sp.speaker: miſ.
sp.p: Men bring tales to me, I defie thee in thy guts, I defie thee, men bring tales to me, thou takeſt me to be one of thine own church doſt: they are no honeſt men that bring tales to thee and ha wiues of their own, and my husbands one of them, go thy waies now.

sp.speaker: wife.
sp.p: I beſeech you madam do but heare me.

sp.speaker: miſ,
sp.p: Hear thee, I haue heard too much of thee, too too much too much, wheres my husband, bring forth my husband, ile teach him to put a difference betwixt Ioan and my ladie I hold him ten pound ont, and yet I wil not ſcold neither, and I had bin an old hag paſt tea ming as his whore is a puritan, it had bid ſomwhat, but being a woman of Gods making, and a ladie of his own, and wearing mine own haire which is much in a ladie of my ſtanding I can tel you, to vſe me thus, fleſh and blood canot induer • , let me come in, open the dore let me come in, O that I were anie vile thing in the world but a ladie that I might ſcold a little.

div.stage: Enter Kalander and philanax Demet, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: So ſo, ſo, take your places, for the ſame bald pated oke is the ſtage, where ye ſhall ſee the part of a doting foole performd by an old man and a young wench,
sp.l: Do worſhipfull Dametas,
The ſame man,
Hath he no fellow acters in his moſt lamentable, commical, hiſtoricall, tragicall, muſicall, paſtoriall.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: None that require any mouthing but his Aſſe and himſelfe, marry then he has Signer Mattocke, a very ſharpe ſaſtyricall humotiſt, and Mounſer le ſpade, but he goes ſomewhat more bluntly to his buſineſſe, yet heele ſerue for mutes, and as good as the beſt to furniſh out the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Kal,
sp.p: But dares Dorus being but Dametus ſeruant ſo abuſe his mad maiſter thus groſely.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: O Lord Sir, their ha ben ſeruing men haue done their Maiſters farre greater abuſe, yet had their wiues conceald it, their eares ſhould neuer haue bin acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is that a faſhion in requeſt.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Altogither Ile aſſure you, but obedience Gentleman the ſean beginnes.

div.stage: Enter Damet as with mattocke and ſpade

sp.speaker: kal.
sp.l: Pray God it be good he ſtaies ſo long,
Ridiculous enough, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: So, ſtand Aſſe, ſtand gentle Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: What countreimen is his Aſſe he ſpeakes ſo familiarly to him.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Ath Citty breede, marrie he picks vp his lyuing ath burs and nettles that grow about the Court gate.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: be in readines good mattocke, play thy part ſweet ſpade, let me ſee Dianaes oke? I held Dianaes oke deuine, true pure gold honeſt, Dorus, fortunate Dametas.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: An excellent come dyan, what life he puts into his part.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So, by thy leaue ſtone, by thy patience honeſt ſtone, the very grauell ſauours of treaſure, this ſames the bed chamber of my Lady Pecunia, and ſee, ſee ſome of her golden haires, more, more, more yet diuine tree, pure gold, honeſt Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, ſoftly, ſoftly, not to faſt, let me not deuoure my content too greedily leaſt like a cormorant I take a ſurfet ont.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh take heed of that maiſter in anie caſe.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p:
Pure mettle, excellent gold: but let me ſee nowe, I ſhall by computation haue ſome three millions of them, I ſome three or foure millions, how ſhall I imploy em to make the moſt profit of
em.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: That would be knowne indeed.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: Ile put out one million to vſe, after the rate af ſeuen ſcore to the hundreth: and yet I wnot, no fie, for then you wil ha my humor brought ath ſtage for a vſerer; to preuent with ſcandalous report, ile put it into my Scribe-maiors hand, and he ſhall deale for mee.

sp.speaker: Kal:
sp.p: Theres is a ſimple cloake to couer his villany.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Tis a very ſhort one,: and paſſing ſlite to hide his knauerie.

sp.speaker: boy.
sp.p: it cannot choſe but be ſeene through,

sp.speaker: dam:
sp.p: An other Milion ile lay to beſtow in Offices. I wil haue welth or ile rake it out ath kennels elſe, chimnies ha ſmoakt for alreadye, and now ile deale vpon ſea-cole and ſalt, now, now, now, it comes, ſweet gold, honeſt Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, deuine gold, how, how, ſhal I adore thee, O let me do the homage of my knees: now nowe, for the tongue of a Poet, tho I hate poetrie worſe then any of the ſeauen deadly ſinnes, I could wiſh my ſelfe a Poet for ſome houre, to write a Poem in the praiſe of my diuine miſtres; and ſee the verie bed wherein her diuinitie is lodged: happy, happy, thrice

sp.speaker: boy.
sp.p: happie Dametas, now like an oreioid louer, let mee open the sheets of my heauenlie miſtris, with reuerence, ſo with humble reuerence, and like a blushing louer that puts out the light ere he preſumes to touch the bed of his loue ſo let me darken the candles of my bodie, mine eies, and firſt bleſſe my hands with touching, next inrich mine ears with hearing, and laſtlie make happie my eies with with ſeeing, and let them convey the ioy downinto the boſome of my thoughts, by degrees, ſoftly by degrees.

sp.speaker: Phi:
sp.p: Did you euer ſee Aſſe make ſuch a ceremonious preparation

sp.speaker: dam:
sp.p: be not offended ſweet miſtris that I preſume to touch.

sp.speaker: phil:
sp.p: a fooles head of your owne,

sp.speaker: Kal:
sp.p: Has a bin at any coſt of al this inuocate for a coxcomb and a bel.

sp.speaker: phil:
sp.p: beshrow my iudgement but he deſetues it,

sp.speaker: boy:
sp.p: And his deſert were neere ſo much, he could but beare away the bel, and ſo you ſaie he doth:

sp.speaker: da:
sp.p: A coxcombe and a bel, oh indignity: damnable ok • , vile and euil accueſt Dorus, vnfortunate Dametas, Diana I tel thee thou art no honeſt goddes to vſe a Gentleman thus. What here a writing, your helpe good ſpectacles, lend me your helpe good ſpectacles, ſome comfortable newes good ſpectacles:
sp.l: Who hath his hire hath well his labours plaſt,
Earth thou didſt ſeeke, and ſtore of earth thou haſt.
He that vaine hopes purſues for loue of pelfe,
Shall looſe his wits and likely finde himſelfe,
Then thinke thy paines rewarded well,
Thou broughſt the foole, beare backe the bell:
Of other matters what enſues
Adonis bower ſhall tell the newes,
Villanous poetry, I am made a flat foole by poetry,
But though I can do em no futther diſgrace, my fatall curſe,
a Wronged gentlemans fatall curſe dwell euer vpon them, Diana
Heere me, and let my words finde gratious acceptance.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Hide your heads, the terrible curſe comes like a ſton vpon you

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Rancor, ſpite, mallice, hate, and all diſaſters,
Strengthen my faith againſt all portaſtors.
May their intents tho pure as chriſtall glaſſes,
Be counted falts and capitall treſpaſſes,
O may their liues and labourd induſtrie,
Though worthy of Apolloes plaud it be
The cleereſt thought in loyalty excelling
Be by ſome Dor preſented for libelling,
when they haue writ a ſeeine in which their braines,
Haue dropt there deereſt ſweets, and their ſwoln vaines,
Emptied their Cundits of their pureſt ſpirit,
As they ſtand gaping to receiue their merrit,
In ſted of plaudities their chiefeſt bliſſes
Let their deſarts be crownd with mewes and hiſſes:
Behinde each poſt and at the gallery corners,
Sit empty guls, ſlight fooles and falſe informers,
Let ſome ſlye Foxe out of diſcreations embers,
Terme them the lands vnneceſſary members,
And like the deere when they haue ſpent their breath,
to make kings ſport let them betorne to death,
Euen by their friends, twold ſet my thoughts a twanging
Might I but ſee one of them go to hanging.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: A paſſing ſtrange curſe and no queſtion he has traueld far for ſome of the rimes,

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: He muſt trauaile further that finds any reaſon int,

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: No matter for reaſon theirs rime enough and that be good.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Som: of it is no better then it ſhould be, or my iudgement deceiues me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
Sure he had ſome reaſon to make this rime,
and a man could pick it out,

sp.speaker: 2 Cap,
sp.p: rather then ile be counted inquiſitiue, mine eares ſhal content themſelues with the rimes onely, and leaue the reaſon to the ſcanning of poets whom it more neerly concerns.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap,
sp.p: But wheres the wag that inuited vs to this banquet of mirth ſhrunke in the wetting?

sp.speaker: 2 cap:
sp.p: tware a rare ieſt now if whilſt the boy kept vs heere in expectation of Dametas gullery his M: had made an eſcape with the duks daughters,

sp.speaker: 1 cap:
sp.p: that or ſome knauery elſe vpon my life, I had the boy in ſhrowd ſuſpiſion at the firſt.

sp.speaker: 2 cap.
sp.p: And this his ſuddaine and ſtolne departure, confirmes it currant

sp.speaker: 2 cap:
sp.p: then we are ſped, for in ſuſpiſions face,
sp.l: I ſee ſome ſuttle ſtratagem in chaſe.

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Will your lordſhip beleeue me now: nay and I ſait your worſhip may ſwert, tho I haue but a (poore as to ſay) hole of mine own I hope the ſpirits haue more denomination ouer me, then to make it a common ſlaughter houſe of carnallity where euery iacke may command fleſh for his mony,

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: No more words ſweet woman I confeſſe I was in the wronge, there is not the hole the Foxe hides his head in: and therefore for the loue of womanhood conceale mine errors, for howſoeuer I complaind tis thy forhed aks, thy temples ha the terrible blow as the ſay, thy husband is a bad man.

sp.speaker: wife,
sp.p: my husband:

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: I, I, good woman thy husband: he is as I ſay a fleſhly member and I fear he hath ouercome the fooliſh thing my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: your daughter ile ſlit her noſe by this light and ſhe wer ten ladies, twas not for nothing my husband ſaid he ſhould meete her this enening at Adonis chappel, but and I come to the godſpeed ont, ile tel em ont ſoundly?

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: I do good woman tel em ont, & ſpare not but in any caſe do not ſcold.

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Why may not a gentlewoman ſcold in a good caſe:

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: I know not what a gentlewoman do in a good caſe, but a lady muſt not in any caſe:

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: tho I may not ſcold I may tel em roundly ont I hope,

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: that may you do lawe,

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: and ile not be mealely mouthd I warrant em, wil you beare me company to the chappell maddam?

sp.speaker: miſo.
sp.p: withall my hart miſtris, what Dorus hath giuen me, ile giue my friend, no foole to company.

div.head: Actus quinti, ſcena prima.
div.stage: Enter the duke at adonis bouer
div.l: Farewell bright ſunne thou lightner of all eies
thou falſt to giue a brighter beame to riſe.
Each tree and ſhrub were tramels of thy haire,
But theſe are wier, for none but kings to weare,
And my rude tonge ſtriuing to blaze her forth,
Like a bad art ſeman doth diſgrace her worth,
but heeres the place, vpon this chriſtall ſtreame:
Where Citherea did vnyoake her teame
Of ſiluer doues, to interchange a kiſſe
With young Adones ſhall I meete my bliſſe:
The gentle minits crownd with chriſtall flowers,
Looſing there youthes, are growne vp perfect howers,
To haſten my delight, the baſhfull moone
that ſince her dalliance with Endimior,
Durſt neuer walke by day is vnder ſaile,
In ſteede of ſheetes has ſpred her ſiluer vaile,
Each gliding brooke and euery buſhy tree
Being tipt with ſiluer were her liuery,
And the dim night to grace our amorous wars,
Hath ſtuck nine ſpheares full of immortall ſtars,
Inſted of pearles the way on which ſhe treads
Is ſtrawd with Chriſtall deu and ſiluer beades.
She comes, her feete makes muſicke with the ground,
And the chaſt ayre is rauiſht with the ſound,
My ſoule flyes forth to meete her: hell my wife,
Her preſence like a murtherer driues the life
Out of my pleaſure breaſt, her ielous cie
Enuyes the heauen of my felicity.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Zelmane, or my husband life or hate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What makes old Autum out a bed ſo late,
that ſnow ſhould goe a woeing to the ſunne
When one • arme kiſſe works her confuſion.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I haue the ieſt, ſuſpition that keepes
Court in my husbands thoughts, ſeeing my loue,
Elect this walke, hath brought him after him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: She dogs her fure, and ſhe to ſhake her off Hath taine ſome other walke Ile place mine eare in diſtance of her will.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Could I but heare the innocent deliuery of his breath, twold be a ſecond iubile of mirth.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Heere comes my loue.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: your loue? Alaſſe poore Duke,
Your forward hopes will meete a barren ſpring,
My ſunne appears.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Fie your loue ſpeakes to loude,
Your ſunnes eclipſt, your date vpon a cloude.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: See how his armes like precious phenix wings,
Spred to imbrace me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Now the Cucko ſings,
Thoſe amorous armes do make a golden ſpace
To hug a Duke.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: But ile fill vp the place.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Thoſe fingers tipt with curious porphery,
Staining Pigmalions matchleſſe imagery,
Like amorous twins all of one mother nurſt,
Contend in curteſie who ſhould touch me firſt.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: ſhould touch me firſt: their ſtrife is vndertook,
To twine a young bay not a farre ſtooping oake.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Young bay, ſtale leſt, that a dry ſapleſſe rinde
should hold young thoughts, and a licentious minde,
Were he but gone now.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.l: Were the Duke away,
My hope, had got the better of the day.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: This is Adonis chappell, I wonder they come not, tho I beare a little learning about me, and a few good clothes, I wold not wiſham to make Balams aſſe a me: for though many fooles take no felicity but in wearing good clothes (tho they be none of their own) I haue a further reach in me.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: I could ban my ſtars.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.p: I curſe my fate.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: That croſſe me thus.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.p: Make me vnfortunate.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: Alas good lady, how her prety feet labour to finde me.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: that my hopes should meete ſuch blacke euents.

sp.speaker: da:
sp.p: O would the trindly night darken her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Would the Moone loſe her light,
That in the boſome of ſome foggy cloud
I might embrace my loue.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But night is purblind
To make a Duke a ſlaue.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: To make a Dutches
wraſtle with amorous paſſions.

sp.speaker: Duk,
sp.l: life a ſpleene
Could my rough breath like a tempeſtious wind,
Blow out heauens candles, leaue the world ſtarke blind,
That it might either haue no eies to ſee:
Or vſe thoſe eies it hath to pleaſure me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.p: Or vſe thoſe eies it hath to pleſure me.

sp.speaker: man.
sp.p: Who woulde ha thought the cold had bene ſo good a muſition: howe it plaies vpon my chappes, and maketh my teeth skippe vp and downe my mouth like a company of virginall Iackes, but I find ſmall muſicke in it, and Mopſa ſhould come now I could doe her little good, yet and ſhe were here, ſhe and I would haue about at cob-nut or at cheri-pit or ſomewhat to keep our ſelues from idlenes, tho ſhe be but a foole, the bables good enough to make ſport with all in the darke and that very word hath ſtarted her.

sp.speaker: Mop,
sp.p: whoſe there Manaſſes.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: yes Mopſa.

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: plain

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I might be madam Mopſa in your mouth, goodman &c. whers Dorus.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: why becauſe he wil not be ſaide to make too much haſt to a bad bargaine, he is not come yet,

sp.speaker: mop,
sp.p: not come, a peſcod on him, but als one I thought at firſt he would make but a foole on me.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: would you haue him mend Gods wormanship?

sp.speaker: mop,
sp.p: But choſe him, ſince he hath buld me with an vrchin, ile goe fetch Raph our horſkeeper, let him that got the calfe keep the cow in a knaues name and he wil, ha you your booke heere.

sp.speaker: man,
sp.p: no matter wench, I can dote wel inough without booke,

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: Nay and ye can dote wel inough your ſelfe, I care for neither of them both, but indeed I loue to haue a thing wel done, for ſaies my mother, a thinge once wel done, is twice done, and I am in her mind for that vp and downe,

sp.speaker: Dut,
sp.l: Whoſe with my Lord the Duke, it cannot be,
Mine eie would not conceale ſuch trechery.

sp.speaker: Dut,
sp.l: Tis not the Dutches ſure, no it is amarous Ioue,
that ſeeing Zelmane paſſionate for loue,
Deſcends to comfort her, Ioue if there be
A powerful Phebus God of poetry,
In deare remembrance of faire Daphnes rape,
to win my loue, lend me ſome ſtranger ſhape,
Such as your ſelues haue worne, that when your fame
is ſung by poets, they maie cote my name,

sp.speaker: Dut,
sp.p: Sure tis my daughter,

sp.speaker: Duk,
sp.l: Daughter: how her eie
Cuts out new formes, new ſhapes of iealouſie:

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: As ſure as death tis she, for ſee they ſtand
like amarous twins, intwiſted hand in hand,
Breaſt againſt breaſt, and that no ioy be miſſing,
To heare diſcourſe, their lips keepe time with kiſsing,
Ile not indurſt impatience grow ſtrong,
And tho a prince, tel him he doth thee wrong.

sp.speaker: duk
sp.l: Do preethe do, this ſweetens al the reſt,
But here would be the elixar of the ieſt,
if whilſt we kept each other at a baie,
A third should come, and beare the hare away.

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: villanous poetrie, vnchriſtian like poetry, I am cozend of my golde by poetrie, robd of my charge by poetrie, made an apparent foole by poetrie vilanous Oke, accurſt Dorus, vnfortunat Dametas: whoſe there my daughter and with Zelmane? a wel-willer to Dorus, a fauorite to poetrie, and therfore enemie to Dametas, come hither mop ſo, a thy fathers bleſsing come not neare her: what Mopſa.

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: yes, whoſe there? Dorus.

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: Confuſion a Dorus, I am thy miſerable father, didſt not ſee Hippolita,

sp.speaker: mop.
sp.p: no by my troth not I? Did ye not ſee Dorus.

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: Poxe of dorus I am vndone madam and thou telſt mee not of Hipolita,

sp.speaker: mo,
sp.p: Pox a Hippolita, I am a dumbe woman and you can tel me newes of Dorus

sp.speaker: da,
sp.p: I had rather ſee ten doruſes hangd then loſe Hippolita,

sp.speaker: mo,
sp.p: I had rather ſee ten fathers damd then loſe my ſweet dorus,

sp.speaker: da,
sp.p: I shal run mad and I find not Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop:
sp.p: I ſhall run franticke and I find not Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.p: Whats heere, I ſhall run mad for Hipolita.

sp.speaker: duke:
sp.p: And I ſhall run franticke and I find not Dorus, I hold my life we haue ſome comedy in hand, we ſhall haue a full ſceane, for here comes more actors.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Aſſures I am a ſinner to God madam, that ſames he.

sp.speaker: muſo
sp.p: What with a brace of wenches, I faith olde brocke, haue I tane you in the maner, is this the fruits of your lying alone? is this your court cuſtome with a wanion, lend mee thy knife, tho I had neither houſe, nor land to giue em, ile beſtow a whores make betwixt you and yet I will not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: mep:
sp.p: What a gudyere aile you mother, are you frampall, know you not your owne daughter.

sp.speaker: miſo.
sp.p: Mopſa, O inſufferable wrong, make thine own natural child thy bawd,

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: Heeres an excellent patterne for wiues to learne to ſcold by

sp.speaker: miſo.
sp.p: What miſtres Amaſon, ha you ſuch a cocking ſpirit, honeſt Women cannot keepe their husbands at home for you: tis not for nothing now I ſee, that the Dutches lookes yellow on you, but ile teare that painted whores face of yours (by this light) and yet I wil not ſcold neither.

sp.speaker: man
sp.p: Madam,

sp.speaker: miſo:
sp.p: ile mad you with a vengeance.

div.stage: The duke and dutches ſtep both forth and reſtraine her.

sp.speaker: dut,
sp.p: Touch not the prince.

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: On your alleagance forbeare, what means this outrage, cannot our private walks be priviledged from your wilde contentious.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: how fares the prince.

sp.speaker: duk:
sp.p: How cheares my good Zelmane?

sp.speaker: man:
sp.p: Zelmane, no Gods my iudge my liege, I am Manaſſes, miſerable Manaſſes, your husbands ſcribe-ma • or madam.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: Manaſſes.

sp.speaker: duk:
sp.p: A foole.

sp.speaker: miſ.
sp.p: My man.

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: And my deere head, alas ſweet loue, what makeſt thou heer.

sp.speaker: m,
sp.p: Mary worke for the hangman, and the Duke be not the more mercifull.

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: Theres ſome deceit in this, Dametas, wheres Hippolita?

sp.speaker: dam:
sp.p: I, I, theres ſom knauery in this: Mopſo wheres Hippolita?

sp.speaker: miſ:
sp.p: doubtles theres ſome villany in this, Mepſo whers Hipolita?

sp.speaker: mep:
sp.p: Thers no plaine dealing in this, Manaſſes wheres Dorus?

sp.speaker: Gry:
sp.p: Anſwere directly, wheres Hippolita?

sp.speaker: dam:
sp.p: Alas madam I knowe not, whilſt I almoſt melted my ſelfe with digging of gold in Dianaes oke, I left her in my wiues charge

sp.speaker: wife
sp.p: And whilſt I ran to Manaſſes, thinking to take my husband & his wife in the manner, I left Hipolita in my daughters chamber

sp.speaker: man:
sp.p: and whilſt I came to Adonis chappel to be toſt in my mariage blankets with Dorus, I left my little dog pearl plucking dazies:

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: Who ſent you to Diannes oke to dig gold?

sp.speaker: Gry:
sp.p: who ſent you to take your husband in Manaſſes houſe?

sp.speaker: wife:
sp.p: dorus.

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: who ſent you to Adonis chappell.

sp.speaker: mep:
sp.p: dorus:

sp.speaker: duke
sp.p: And who turnd you into this ſhape:

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: They that I feare haue made guls of vs all, Zelmane, and dorus:

sp.speaker: duke:
sp.p: we are all ſimply gulde, and ſee where the Sunne ſcarce halfeready, skippes from his Eaſterne bed, ſmiling at our gullery:

sp.speaker: dem:
sp.p: Come wheres this luſty wit-maiſter.

sp.speaker: Liſa:
sp.p: the keeper of this loue-lottery,

sp.speaker: dem:
sp.p: This gallant luventus of fourſcore, that like my Lady of the Lake, diſplaies againſt al commers.

sp.speaker: Liſan.
sp.p: May a couple of plaine witted princes haue a ſight of your prizes:

sp.speaker: dem:
sp.p: Where be theſe Ladies ha? ha your wits had ſuch a skirmiſhing that the two maides haue loſt their heads in the conflict.

sp.speaker: dut;
sp.p: Heads, I and bodyes to my Lorde, and all at one ſhot, and which is worſe our wits are ſo ſcatered with the terible blow that to be plaine we are ſcarce our owne men againe.

sp.speaker: dem:
sp.p: then you haue had ſome knock • ng,

sp.speaker: mun:
sp.p: ſo it appeares by the ſtorie my Lord:

sp.speaker: liſan:
sp.p: How ſay y • u my lady, what Oule ſings out of that Iuy buſh

sp.speaker: dem:
sp.p: was your 〈◊〉 knighted in this laſt action:

sp.speaker: man:
sp.p: I am 〈…〉 ch a foole, I loue my lord, I am no knight, I am Manaſſes, they made a plaine foole.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: the onely were, for the gaurded foole is out of requeſt: but faith my liedge how did your oppoſites behaue themſelues, did they win the Wenches faire at the point?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: At the very puſh of inuention, and went off cleere vntoucht,

sp.speaker: Liſa:
sp.p: And could you draw no blood of their wits:

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Not a drop.

sp.speaker: Liſa.
sp.p: Nor demetrius neither, nor Manaſſes?

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: Neither, to our owne diſgrace be it ſpoken, the carriage of their ſtratagem deſerues applauſe, and I held it a credit to reſt captiue to ſuch valiant conquerors?

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: Why ſo be, I like a man that wil confeſſe his error.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: It merrits comiſſeration madam and my liege, not to detract from our worth: your eare, we two are the parties you wot on.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Ware you the men?

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: No he was the man, mary I was the woman in the moone, that made you walk al this laſt night like the man in the miſt, I could ſay ſomewhat to you to Madam as for demetrius & his man let them ſtand like fooles as they are.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Can it be poſſible.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No, no, we are guls, Innocent ſots, but lante tanta, the girles are ours we haue won em away to dargiſon.

sp.speaker: Liſa:
sp.p: Come we haue won the conqueſt, and thats ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You are a manaſſes tis not ſufficient: aha not Hercules for iole, Ioue, for Danue, Apollo for daphene, pan for Si • ne, nay the whole pack of their piperly godheads could a diſchargd a ſtratagem with more ſpirit of al merit, an ambling nag and a down a down we haue borne her away to dargiſon.

sp.speaker: dut.
sp.p: Twas the moſt rareſt, diuineſt, Metaphiſicalſt, piece of inuention, that, what ſay you my leige.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: I giue your deſarts their full merrit you haue gotten equality

sp.speaker: iulio:
sp.p: All the wenches gaue you:

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas what ſpirits vnder the moone could haue detainder but know that her cherry red lip, a downe, a downe.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: Truſt me but you haue deſerued high commendation.

sp.speaker: iulio:
sp.p: Your merrit ſtood of the vpper ſtaire of admiration.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Why thou haſt a pretty reliſh of wit, now that canſt ſee the broad ey of my deſart at a little hole of demonſtration.

sp.speaker: iulo.
sp.p:
your deſart ſaue me free, you haue done a moſt (to vſe your own
phraſe) Metaphyſicall piece of ſeruice, but you had ſome helpe int queſtionles,

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: I do not thinke but the ladies had ſome hand int:

sp.speaker: da,
sp.p: A finger, I confeſſe a finger by the hope of perſeuerance, a very litle finger.

sp.speaker: iuli,
sp.p: I thought aſmuch by the making of the ieſt.

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.p: I cannot detract from the ladies worth, for I knowem for excellent work women,

sp.speaker: dam,
sp.p: work women fit to make tailors men.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I by my faith do I, nay your beſt tailors are arrant botchers to em, you ſhal haue a lady make an end of a ſute, a court ſute, eſpecially when all the tailors in a countrey know not how to ſet a ſtich int.

sp.speaker: dorus,
sp.p: Some ordinary ſute perhaps.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: your beſt court ſuits that are, are finiſht by ladies, I haue known a ſuit my ſelfe lien a making and maring 3, 4, and fiue yeare together and then a lady hath deſpacht it in a month with a wet finger, ſuch a finger might the ladies haue in your plot.

sp.speaker: de,
sp.p: neuer wet a finger by this ſun.

sp.speaker: iuli.
sp.p: Then ſhe helpt you with one dry ieſt or other, but and we may be ſo bold: faith where are the ladies?

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: ſure enogh I warrant you, ſome fooles now would haue kept em heare and haue beene guld on em againe, and laught at age, bvt to preuent all danger, we haue ſhipt em home for Lacedemon,

sp.speaker: iulio:
sp.p: to Lacedemon, your ſunne of wit ſhines but dimly in that methinkes, to whoſe charge haue you truſted em?

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: to them we durſt, nay you muſt thinke wee are no fooles,

sp.speaker: iu.
sp.p: Fooles: nay deepe wit, and pollicy forbid.

sp.speaker: Da,
sp.p: We had no ſooner their ſurpriſall, but we had diſguiſe ready, a ſhip ready, a couple of luſty friends ready, the Lacedemons intelligencers:

sp.speaker: iuli.
sp.p: durſt you truſt ſuch pretious iewels in ſuch ruſty caſkets:

sp.speaker: da:
sp.p: durſt, our health, our liues: why they were my tenants, nay you muſt thinke we ſifted them, we are no fooles in that neither.

sp.speaker: hip:
sp.p: If in any thing your wits deſerue the bable tis in that,

sp.speaker: iuli:
sp.p: none but fools wold haue commited ſuch ineſtimable peeres to a couple of ſtrangers:

sp.speaker: hip:
sp.p: And in a ſhip to,

sp.speaker: iu:
sp.p: And vnder ſaile to.

sp.speaker: dut:
sp.p: And vnfurniſht of friends to.

sp.speaker: du:
sp.p: And without shipping to follow em to.

sp.speaker: iu.
sp.p: you were no fooles in any thing but that, & in that not to flatter, you expreſſe the true shape of folly and merely merrit the name of fools.

sp.speaker: da.
sp.p: What will you ſaie now when theſe fellowes ſurrender vs our loues?

sp.speaker: Aunt
sp.p: Weele diſcharge you and ſet their names down for gulls in your ſtead.

sp.speaker: De:
sp.p: you know the prouerbe when the skie fals we ſhal haue larks.

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: And when you can bring proofe that we are coſend of our Wenches weele be the woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: Why then we haue once ſpringed a couple of woodcockes.

sp.speaker: Aunt:
sp.p: Doe you know theſe? Who are the fooles now?

sp.speaker: deme:
sp.p: Violletta.

sp.speaker: Liſand:
sp.p: My Hippolita:

sp.speaker: dam:
sp.p: What a ſtrange change is heere:

sp.speaker: Hippo:
sp.p: yes faith gallants you haue very ſtrange carding and you knew al, but I hope youle offer vp your cards and yeild the ſet loſt.

sp.speaker: dam:
sp.p: Guls:

sp.speaker: Liſan:
sp.p: And abuſd ile looſe my life before I looſe my honor,

sp.speaker: dam.
sp.p: Honor, and life before ile looſe my loue:

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: Nay gentlemen we bar all violence, the liberty of our challenge was to all alike equally free, and ſince theſe by faire play haue won em, it ſtands with our honor to ſee them peaceably poſſeſt of em, then ſurely take em, for though you weare the breeches giue vs leaue to ſtand a little:

sp.speaker: Hippo:
sp.l: why father iſt not time that we were ſped
Tis a great charge to keepe a maidenhead,
Looſe it we muſt and to preuent il courſe,
Better to giuet then haue it ſtolne perforce,
if you be pleaſd let enuy doe her worſt
Spit out her poyſon or containt and burſt?
Welcome to all, to all a kind god night,
They trewly liue, that liue in ſcorne of ſpight.

div.p: In B. the laſt page, for Lord, read loue cannot be ſaued.
